CULTURAL FOUNDATION)
It opened to the public in 
1989 and has, ever since,  
been organising major painting,  
sculpture, photography and 
architecture exhibitions in 
collaboration with other local 
educational and cultural 
agencies. Events related to  
the history of the city and  
the greater area also take  
place there. The collection 
includes approx. 250 pieces  
on painting, sculpture, pottery,  
mosaics, murals and 
engraving.']
reference_contexts: ['The historic center of Thessaloniki features traditional commercial areas like Vlali Square, known for coffee shops and restaurants, and a memorial for MP Gr. Lamprakis. The Vatikioti market and Athonos Square offer shops selling produce, spices, and various goods, along with tavernas and ouzo restaurants. Bezesteni, a rectangular building from the late 15th century, serves as a textile and jewelry market with over 110 shops. Stoa Saul, completed in 1881 and rebuilt after a fire, combines neo-renaissance and art deco styles and is now an entertainment venue. Vas. Irakleiou, formerly known as Fragkomachalas, has transformed from a banking area to a commercial and entertainment hub, with popular tavernas and traditional marketplaces offering high-quality foodstuffs.', 'The input consists of the number 112 repeated twice.', 'The text describes notable landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the OTE Tower, built in 1969, which serves as a telecommunications hub and features a rotating café with stunning views. It also mentions the Alexandreio Melathron, a historic sports arena constructed in 1966, which has hosted various significant events and is now home to the Aris basketball team. Additionally, Angelaki Street is highlighted for its vibrant cafés and bars popular among university students, as well as the presence of several radio stations. The area surrounding the 3rd Army Corps is also noted, with its historical significance and architectural features.', 'Kalochori, located 5 km west of the city center, is a rapidly growing residential suburb known for its industrial character and local tavernas. The Gallikos River runs along its west edge, offering facilities for picnicking and relaxation. The river delta and Kalochori lagoon are home to diverse wildlife, including herons and flamingoes. The surrounding wetland area, protected by the Ramsar Convention, is part of the Natura 2000 network and offers free tours. Sindos, situated about 9 km northwest of Kalochori, has grown significantly due to the Thessaloniki Industrial Park.', 'The area features historical sites, including a World War II gun emplacement, and is home to diverse salt marshes and wetlands that shelter 178 bird species like flamingoes and cormorants. To reach the location, take the 71 or 71A bus from the Railway Station Stop to N. Michaniona, or use bus lines 02 and 02A to A.S. IKEA station and then transfer to buses 72, 72A, or 72B. If driving, follow Ethinikis Antistasis, Georgikis Scholis, and Michanionas avenues.', "The text describes various museums in Thessaloniki, Greece, including a cinema museum showcasing projectors and films from 1910, a photography museum founded in 1997 with over 100,000 photographic objects from 1890-1980, and the Olympic Museum, which focuses on Olympic and Paralympic memorabilia. Additionally, it mentions the 'Christos Tsiggiridis' Radio Museum, featuring equipment from the founder of the first radio station in the Balkans. Each museum hosts educational programs and temporary exhibitions, contributing to the cultural landscape of the city.", 'The Jewish quarter in Europe retains its traditional character, featuring Roman, Ottoman, and Industrial age monuments in districts like Kyriotissa, Panagia Dexia, and Makariotissa. Visitors can explore the award-winning Public Central Library and enjoy local parks. Vergina, located 63 km SW of Thessaloniki, is accessible by car, intercity bus, or train. Dion, an archaeological site under the Olympus mountain range, was a sacred place for ancient Macedonians, dedicated to Zeus and the Muses. The site includes the Vafyras sacred springs, the temple of Demeter, and the Sanctuary of Zeus Hypsistos. Dion flourished until the 5th century AD when it was abandoned due to seismic activity.', 'The historic centre features Valaoritou Street and nearby streets filled with cafés, bars, and restaurants. Irakleiou, serves as an interesting shopping centre.', 'The Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association is located in Piraeus, while the Thessaloniki Marina is in Aretsou Kalamaria. The city also features a range of cultural institutions, including the State Museum of Contemporary Art and the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki.', "The text describes several museums in Thessaloniki, including a Holocaust exhibition that memorializes the local Jewish community, particularly the 49,000 members sent to concentration camps. The Museum of the Macedonian Struggle showcases the history of Macedonia's fight for freedom against the Ottoman Turks, with various rooms dedicated to different aspects of this struggle. Lastly, the Ataturk Museum displays exhibits across two floors, highlighting the life and legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.", "The text describes notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including Agios Panteleimonas Church, which was originally part of a monastery and later converted into a mosque, featuring murals from the 13th-14th centuries. The church contains significant mosaics and a basement Krypt, believed to be the site of Saint Demetrius's martyrdom, and has been used for cultural events since 1988.", 'Ano Poli, or Old Town, features notable areas like Tsinari, Terpsithea Square, and Romfei Square. Terpsithea Square showcases remarkable buildings, a playground, and the Tϋrbe of Musha Baba, a late Ottoman monument. Visitors can explore significant archaeological sites, historical towns, and natural reserves. Ancient Pella, once the capital of Macedon, thrived under King Philip II and became a major cultural center before its decline after Roman conquest. Today, it is a vibrant area frequented by locals and tourists, lined with cafés and bars, and features a wide pedestrian area by the sea. The avenue is also home to several notable landmarks, including various mansions and the State Orchestra of Thessaloniki.", 'The document outlines a guide to Thessaloniki, including its history, various walking tours of the city, information on museums, day excursions, nightlife, gastronomy, and tips for touring with children.', 'The text describes the historical significance of various structures in ancient Macedonia, including a palace with a peristyle, a monumental gateway, and a temple dedicated to Hercules. The city is known for its hospitality, artistic events, and exceptional culinary traditions. Its strategic location allows easy access to renowned archaeological sites, natural wonders, and the monastic state of Agion Oros. The Wine Producers Association offers excursions through the 'Wine Roads of North Greece,' combining visits to wineries with historical sites. Families can enjoy various fun activities and games throughout the city.", "The Lazare church in Paris, once a hospital and refugee center, was declared a historic monument in 1980 and renovated in 1997 for cultural events in Thessaloniki. It now serves as a multi-purpose venue, housing the National Theatre of Northern Greece, a café-restaurant, and hosting outdoor performances. The area also features five old tobacco warehouses, remnants of the city's tobacco trade, with one converted into a luxury hotel and others housing educational and commercial spaces. Additionally, the Stavroupoli Botanical Garden spans 0.5 hectares, showcasing over 1000 plant species and providing recreational facilities. The Serbian monument is located in the Zeitenlik allied military cemetery.", 'The number 114 is repeated twice.', "Eleftherias Square, located near the harbor, served as a parking lot and was the site where 50,000 Jewish residents were gathered by German forces in 1943. The square is surrounded by notable buildings, including the National Bank of Greece and the Ionian and Popular Bank, showcasing late neoclassicism and eclectic styles. Kalapothaki Street, starting from the Ladadika area, features pedestrianized sections with neoclassical and Bauhaus-style buildings, popular cafés, and the historic Stein Building. The port area is one of the largest in the southeastern Mediterranean, with a rich history dating back to Constantine the Great's time.", "The Orphanos Church, built in the 1310s as part of Vlatadon Monastery, features exquisite 14th-century murals and is one of Thessaloniki's best-preserved monuments. The city walls of Thessaloniki were established shortly after its founding and underwent significant changes under Theodosius I in 390 AD. Over the centuries, the walls were reinforced during Venetian and Turkish rule, resulting in a total length of 7 km, with only 3 km remaining today. The walls are notable for their impressive height and width, contributing to their archaeological and cultural significance. For a comprehensive understanding of Byzantine art in the city, visitors are encouraged to explore the Museum of Byzantine Culture.", "Greece, a parliamentary republic and EU member since 1981, has a population of approximately 10.8 million. Thessaloniki, the second-largest city, is located 510 km north of Athens and has over 1 million residents. The euro has been the national currency since 2001, and the international calling code is +30. Thessaloniki experiences a temperate Mediterranean climate with average temperatures ranging from 5°C in January to 24°C in August. Other notable festivals include Carnival and Pentecost. For consulate information, contact local authorities in Thessaloniki.", "The text describes several museums, including the room of Kemal Ataturk's mother, which exhibits his personal items and documents. This museum also has a collection of contemporary Greek art and hosts temporary exhibitions.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki, particularly the Ladadika area, has transformed from a downgraded region post-WWII to a vibrant hotspot filled with restaurants, clubs, and live music venues since the 1990s. Key starting points for exploration include Morichovou square and Petrakaki square, where notable sights like the Ottoman Post Office Mansion can be found. Significant buildings include the Kazes Building, designed by Xenophon Paionidis in 1924, and the Agios Minas Church, which has historical roots dating back to early Christianity.', 'Thessaloniki has historically been a key stopover for East-West trade. Today, its town center offers a vibrant shopping experience with traditional marketplaces and modern commercial areas. Visitors can find a variety of goods, including food, clothing, and antiques, at reasonable prices. Notable shopping spots include Bit-Pazar for second-hand items and the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall, which features over 200 shops and entertainment options. Other popular areas include the Hirsch Building Mall and Plateia Mall. For budget-friendly shopping, Venizelou St., Egnatia St., and Agiou Dimitriou St. are recommended. The city also has modern shopping centers in Kalamaria and its suburbs.', "The Historic Centre features a blend of modern and traditional Macedonian architecture, including notable sites such as the Acheiropoiitos church, built in 1818, and the Nedelkou Building from 1909, which now houses the Mount Athos Centre. The Galerius Arch, a significant landmark from 295-305 AD, commemorates Galerius' victory over the Persians and is a popular meeting spot. Nearby, the Rotunda and Panagia Dexia church, which contains a rare icon of the Virgin Mary, add to the area's historical richness.", "The text describes various museums in Thessaloniki, including the archaeological museum that showcases excavated sites and the process of maintaining an archaeological museum. Recently, Valaoritou Street has emerged as a nightlife hotspot, especially in summer. The Slaughterhouse area hosts large venues for live Greek music and the biggest clubs in the city.", "The text describes various locations and landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the historic center, the White Tower area, and notable streets. The area around the White Tower is a central hub where major roads converge, offering views of the sea and a vibrant atmosphere with shops and cafés.", 'The International Book Fair in Thessaloniki is an annual event held in the HELEXPO-TIF exhibition center, attracting professionals and book lovers. The Society for Macedonian Studies is a key cultural institution in Thessaloniki, focusing on the preservation and promotion of Macedonian history and culture. Olympus, the highest mountain in Greece, is noted for its biodiversity and as a popular destination for hiking. Ancient Pydna, once an administrative center under Macedon, faced decline after Roman conquest and was eventually deserted.', 'The Greek National Tourism Organisation promotes tourism in Greece through its website, www.visitgreece.gr.', 'The 6th walk in Thessaloniki highlights several must-see landmarks along NEA PARALIA and VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE. Additionally, visitors can explore a rare Macedonian tomb from the 3rd century BC and the neoclassical Ippokrateio Hospital built in 1891.', 'The text describes various museums in Macedonia, including sections on antiquities from the 2nd to 4th centuries AD, prehistoric items, and temporary exhibitions. The Terpsithea District features well-planned urban spaces, including the old military camp and Lebet mosque, which will be transformed into a park. The Jewish cemetery, established in 1938, contains remnants from a previous cemetery destroyed during WWII. Additionally, the Moni Lazariston, built in 1886 by Lazarist monks, is an impressive historical site.', "The text describes various streets and locations in Thessaloniki, highlighting their historical significance and current status. The surrounding area features mostly unremarkable buildings but also historic sites, including sections of the city's west walls and archaeological monuments. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, is mentioned as a significant structure that began construction in 1939 and became operational in 1951.", "The historic centre features the White Tower, originally known as the Tower of the Janissaries, which served as a jail and now hosts exhibitions on Thessaloniki's history. Previously named Hamidiye Boulevard, it is now home to various cultural institutions, including the Theatre of the Society for Macedonian Studies and popular cafés and bars nearby.", 'The text describes various historical sites in a town, including Main Street, which was lined with shops and public buildings. A polygonal building served as a roofed marketplace, while remnants of Early Christian Walls were found nearby. Additionally, the text mentions a climbing route in Olympus National Park and the Petralona Museum, showcasing prehistoric human activity.', 'The Agora, a 4th century BC building complex, served as the administrative and cultural hub of the town, featuring a large court and various commercial shops. The Palace, located on a northern hill, dates back to the 4th century BC and includes a peristyle and royal quarters. Aristotelous Street, a pedestrianized historic boulevard, connects to Egnatia Street.", 'The text describes various historical sites in Thessaloniki, including the Hippodrome, which was a center of social activity until 390 AD when a massacre led to its closure. It highlights the Thessaloniki History Centre and the 18th-century Agios Antonios church nearby. The area is rich in history and cultural significance, making it a must-visit for tourists.', 'The number 116 is repeated twice.', 'The map of Thessaloniki highlights various public agencies and services, including the G.N.T.O. Additionally, the map includes 19th to 20th-century landmarks like Aristotelous Square and the YMCA of Thessaloniki.', "The text describes several significant Byzantine monuments, including their architectural features and historical transformations. The first is a tetrastyle cross-in-square church that became a mosque, obscuring its original murals. The Panagia Chalkeon Church, built in 1128, showcases the 'School of Constantinople' architecture and was also converted into a mosque. Lastly, Agia Sofia Church, built in the mid-7th century, is a replica of the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople, highlighting its historical significance.", 'The historic center of Thessaloniki features a shopping mall that was reshaped between 1995-1997, retaining its original exterior while now housing shops, cinemas, cafés, and restaurants around a central atrium. Notable buildings from the early 20th century are located at the junction of Tsimiski and Karolou Dil Streets, currently serving as shops and offices. Modiano Market, built in 1922, is a prominent glass-roofed structure with 140 food shops and popular restaurants. The Vlali-Kapani and Athonos-Vatikioti Markets, designed by Ernest Hébrard, feature two-storeyed malls with archways and are connected to Aristotelous Street.', 'The text describes notable buildings in the historic center of Thessaloniki, including the YMCA Building, which features a mix of neo-colonial and Byzantine architecture and houses various sports and cultural facilities. The Archaeological Museum, designed by P. Karantinos and inaugurated in 1962, showcases modernist architectural design and includes spaces for exhibitions and events. A prominent church, Agioi Theodoroi, built on a 7th-century Byzantine site, offers stunning city views. Nearby, Elpidos Street has refugee houses being transformed into a Cultural Neighbourhood. Additionally, it highlights the historical significance of Vergina (Aiges), the former capital of Macedon, detailing its importance from the 10th-8th century BC until its destruction by the Romans in 168 BC. Notable sites include the Hirsch villa, a former police department, and the Chatzilazarou Residence, built in 1890. The Marokou Residence, previously a boarding school, now houses a Traffic Police Department. The Mehmet Kapanci Villa, constructed in 1893, served various significant roles, including housing military leaders and high schools, and is now part of the Thessaloniki Cultural Centre. The Ahmet Kapanci Villa, built in 1905, features eclectic architectural styles and has housed various organizations over the years, including the Red Cross and NATO services.', "The Historic Centre features Plateia Dikastirion, a green square where the Court House was planned but halted due to the discovery of the Ancient Roman Forum. The Roman Forum, a 2-hectare area, served as the city's social and religious center during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd to mid-3rd centuries AD. The site includes a large square with traces of marble paving and a double underground Cryptoporticus, likely used as a public storehouse, featuring an early Christian mural.", "The text describes various historical and architectural landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the West of the Centre-Stavroupoli inaugurated in 1962, which connects the city to Greece and the Balkans. The Old Railway Station, built in 1894, is now a cargo station and was historically significant during the German occupation. The Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), constructed by the Ottomans in 1546, served as a city stronghold and remains well-preserved. The De La Salle Complex, built in 1926, now houses the city's Administrative Courts, while the Vienni Hotel, established in 1925, reflects the eclectic architectural trends of its time and currently contains private offices.", 'Noesis is a unique science center and technology museum in Greece, completed in 2004, featuring exhibitions, a digital library, and an amphitheater. It can be accessed via public transport or car from Thessaloniki. The seaside areas of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada, located 20 km from the city center, were settled by refugees in 1923 and have since developed into popular suburbs and resorts with Blue Flag beaches and various amenities. The Museum for the Macedonian Struggle, a neo-classical building, is noted for its historical significance and previous functions. Nearby, the metropolitan church of Agios Gregorios Palamas showcases Byzantine architecture, and the Ecclesiastical Museum offers a collection related to the church.', "Dion, located 87 km SW of Thessaloniki, features a significant neolithic settlement, early-Christian basilicas, and a 10th-century basilica with impressive mosaics. Visitors can reach Dion via national roads or local buses from Katerini. The Petralona Cave, discovered in 1959, is notable for its prehistoric findings, including a 200,000-400,000-year-old skull, making it one of Europe's oldest archaeological sites. The cave showcases various prehistoric items and is partially open to visitors. Halkidiki, known for its beautiful beaches and rich history, is a popular tourist destination south of Thessaloniki, featuring three peninsulas: Kassandra, Sithonia, and Athos.", 'The museum features a collection of over 2,500 corkscrews from the 16th to 20th centuries, categorized by mechanical and non-mechanical types, as well as by gender usage. It includes explanatory texts and photographs. Additionally, touch screens display a glossary of viticulture and wine-making terms. Room B showcases the historical significance of wine through tools and vessels, along with scenes from films and photos related to wine production and consumption.', "The text describes significant Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including the UNESCO-listed church that was once a cathedral and later converted into a mosque, showcasing impressive mosaics and murals. It also highlights the Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, a typical example of Byzantine architecture from around 1340, adorned with depictions of Christ's Ascension. Additionally, the Rotunda, built in 306 AD, is noted for its massive dome and preserved mosaics, which were later converted into a mosque. The surrounding area includes the small church of Agios Georgios, further enriching the historical context of these monuments.", "Thessaloniki, founded in the 4th century BC, has maintained its urban character as a civic center influenced by various empires and multicultural groups. Its rich history includes Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman rule, with contributions from Jews, Latins, Armenians, and Greeks. The city's numerous historical monuments reflect its cosmopolitan nature. The White Tower area is a bustling part of Thessaloniki, where the old seafront meets the new waterfront.", 'The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the impressive complex of 14 listed industrial buildings from 1854, originally owned by the French and later by the Allatini family. It mentions the Vafopouleio Cultural Centre, inaugurated in 1983, which hosts art exhibitions, performances, and has three libraries. The Ouziel quarter features picturesque semi-detached houses built for tramway workers, now a protected architectural monument. Sofouli Street connects eastern districts with Kalamaria, lined with trees, shops, and offering views of the city. Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, once a favorite promenade, is noted for its green surroundings along the waterfront.', "Thessaloniki offers various outdoor activities such as hiking and mountain biking in the suburban forests of Seich Sou and Chortiatis, as well as relaxing by the Deltas of Gallikos and Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas rivers. Educational programs for children are available in most museums, particularly at the unique Children's Museum. The Noesis Science Centre and Technology Museum provides fun and educational experiences related to science and technology. Visitors can also explore the Environmental Dinosaur Theme Park and the Mammoth Museum. For beach lovers, there are beautiful seaside options in Thessaloniki and Halkidiki. Families can enjoy the Magic Park, Greece's largest amusement park, and WaterLand, which features various water attractions.", 'The text describes various historical and cultural sites in a city, focusing on Agia Sofia Square, which features greenery and is shaped by the 1890 fire. It highlights the pedestrianized Agias Sofias Street, notable buildings like the Longos Building and Chatzidimitriou Building, and the monument commemorating the Genocide of Pontic Greeks. Navarinou Square is presented as a vibrant student area with cafés, bars, and cultural venues, along with a fountain and playground. The area also includes shops selling books, records, and antiques, and encourages visits to the nearby church of Nea Panagia, dating back to 1727.', 'The text describes day excursions from Thessaloniki, highlighting the monastic state of Mount Athos, which features 20 inhabited monasteries and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. It provides directions to Petralona Cave, located 53 km southeast of Thessaloniki, accessible by coach and taxi or by car. Additionally, it mentions the Lakes Area northeast of Thessaloniki, a National Park with diverse ecosystems ideal for outdoor activities. The area is managed by an agency that offers tours, and visitors are encouraged to try local fish dishes. Lastly, it notes the town of Lagadas, known for its fire-walking custom and modern spa facilities with historical Byzantine bathtubs.', 'The text describes two museums: Noesis and Gerovassiliou Wine Museum. Noesis focuses on interactive learning with exhibits like a car exhibition, a planetarium, a cosmotheatre, and a virtual reality simulator. It also offers educational programs on renewable energy and science. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, established in 2008, showcases the history of wine-making and features collections that illustrate the journey of wine, food pairings, and wine-making equipment. Both museums emphasize visitor engagement and education.', 'Thessaloniki offers various tourism services including an Info Point at Aristotelous Square, open Mon-Fri from 9 am to 5 pm. The Thessaloniki Tourism Organisation provides information and assistance, reachable at 2310 279.282 or via email at welcome@thessaloniki.travel. The Tourist Police, available at 1571, assists tourists with information and minor disputes. The city has over 130 hotels with a capacity of approximately 13,000 beds, and inquiries can be made through the Thessaloniki Hotels Association. For conferences, the Thessaloniki Convention Bureau can be contacted for well-equipped venues. Organized excursions can be arranged through local travel agencies, and car rental services are available through the Car Rental Agencies Association. Yacht charters can be organized via the Hellenic Yacht Brokers Association.', 'The text describes the historical and cultural significance of suburbs and outskirts of Thessaloniki, including ancient tombs and a Neolithic settlement. It provides directions to Kalochori via bus or car. Kalamaria, a prominent suburb, features green spaces and a shopping center, with a history of Greek refugees settling there in the 1920s. Key sites include Sofouli Street, the Little Palace (formerly a royal residence), and the Kodra former military camp, which is being transformed into a park. Excavations in Kodra revealed an ancient settlement, possibly linked to Ancient Thermi.', "The Museum of Greek Children’s Art showcases the creativity of children, depicting Greek history, tradition, and culture through their artwork. It is one of the few museums worldwide dedicated to children's art.", "Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to Roman times, connecting Dyrrhachium and Constantinople. It runs from Dimokratia Square to the TIF grounds and the Aristotle University, serving as a bustling shopping area with notable eclectic and art deco buildings. Key attractions include Kolomvou Square, a lively hub with cafés and bars, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is currently undergoing renovations for an exhibition. The street splits the city's historic center and features important monuments worth observing.", "The text describes various cultural and historical sites in Thessaloniki, including a small museum dedicated to the founder of modern Turkey, the Teloglion Foundation of Art with its modern facilities, and the Kaftanzogleio Stadium, which was the largest in Greece until 1982 and is home to the city's oldest football team, Iraklis. The stadium also hosted events during the 2004 Athens Olympic Games and is near the Olympic Museum.", 'The area along NEA PARALIA features 12 Theme Gardens covering 76,657 m2, ideal for leisure activities. Notable gardens include the Garden of Alexander, Garden of the Seasons with an amphitheater, and the Garden of Music for events. A 3 km cycle path is available, along with the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall, inaugurated in 2000, is inspired by Byzantine architecture and hosts various performances and conferences. It includes a main hall for 1464 attendees and a neighboring building with additional facilities. The Depot Area, named after historic tram depot buildings, retains traces of its older atmosphere. The Allatini Mills and the church of Saints Cyril and Methodius are also significant sites in the area.', "The Historic Centre features archaeological sites from the late Roman period, including shops from the 1st to 13th century and the underground Museum of the Roman Forum. A restored Odeon from the 2nd-4th century AD is now used for cultural events, alongside a mint and archive office. A round bathhouse dating back to the 1st century BC was also discovered, along with various artifacts like mosaics, sculptures, and coins. The forum is notable for the 'Enchanted Ones,' a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with surviving Corinthian columns, which were relocated to the Louvre in 1864. Bit-Pazar, a vibrant market area with antique shops and restaurants, was built in the 1930s and has become popular among students. Nearby, the Jewish Monastirioton Synagogue is the only one to survive World War II. The Experimental School, designed by architect D. Pikionis, was constructed from 1936 to 1938.", "The phrase 'Follow Greece Everywhere' suggests a strong interest or commitment to exploring and engaging with Greek culture, history, and lifestyle in various contexts.", "Thessaloniki has a rich history marked by the settlement of various communities, particularly from the Iberian Peninsula, and a period of harmony among ethnic groups from the 16th to 18th centuries. The city evolved into a significant trade center by the 18th century and became more cosmopolitan with railway connections established in the late 19th century. Major events include a devastating fire in 1890, the Greek army's seizure of the city in 1912 after five centuries of Ottoman rule, and a significant fire in 1917 that led to extensive rebuilding. The city faced challenges during the Asia Minor Catastrophe in 1922-1923, receiving many Greek refugees. The German occupation in 1943 resulted in the tragic loss of a large portion of the Jewish population. Thessaloniki experienced a severe earthquake in 1978, and later, in 1997 and 2014, it was recognized as the European Capital of Culture and the European Youth Capital, respectively.", 'The Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art features a permanent collection of 1,800 works by notable Greek and foreign artists and has hosted over 100 exhibitions. The museum also has a library with over 2,500 specialized titles. The Teloglion Foundation of Art, established in 1972, houses a significant collection including Hellenistic statuettes and works by renowned 19th and 20th-century artists, along with hosting temporary exhibitions and educational programs. The Municipal Gallery displays over 1,000 artworks, focusing on Thessalonian artists from 1898 to 1967, and is part of the cultural offerings in Thessaloniki, which also includes the Society for Macedonian Studies and the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum.', 'The text describes various historical sites, including the Sanctuary of Isis, which is half-sunk in water and dedicated to the Egyptian goddess. It also mentions the Sanctuary of Olympian Zeus, completed in the Hellenistic period, featuring a large altar and Roman theatre. The Hellenistic Theatre, built in the 3rd century BC, hosts modern events today. The Sanctuary of Asklipios, active until the 3rd century AD, is noted for a statue of the goddess Hygeia. Additionally, the Cemetery Basilica from the 5th century is described, along with fortified walls originally constructed by Cassander, which have been reconstructed over time.', 'The historic centre features a museum with exhibits of ancient human skulls, including those from the Axios river and Petralona Cave. Notable sites include the Observatory, built in 1954, and Agiou Dimitriou Street, one of the oldest roads in the city, surrounded by Interwar Period architecture. The area has seen an influx of Eastern European emigrants who have opened shops and restaurants, adding diversity. Key attractions include the Dioikitirio, a neoclassical building from 1891 that now houses the Ministry of Macedonia-Thrace, and the Agios Dimitrios church.', 'The text describes several historical sites in the historic center, including Yeni Hamam, built in 1531, which served as a bathing place until 1944-45. Alaca Imaret, constructed in 1484, features skilled masonry and is occasionally used for cultural events. The Profitis Ilias Church and Panagia Lagoudiani Church, a 14th-century Byzantine basilica, are also mentioned, with the latter honoring the Virgin Mary and Saint Demetrius. Additionally, the Ataturk Museum, located in the former residence of Kemal Ataturk, showcases his life and includes a café. Lastly, Kaftanzogleio Stadium is noted as the largest stadium in the city.', 'Epanomi is a picturesque town 25 km SE of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful beaches and a wetland that hosts over 80 bird species. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, unique in northern Greece, is located nearby. Nea Michaniona, a major fishing center 32 km S of Thessaloniki, features the largest fleet of deep-sea fish boats in Greece and a vibrant seafront with cafés and tavernas. Angelochori, a small village near Nea Michaniona, offers stunning views of the Olympus massif and historical Ottoman architecture. The area is also recognized for its high-quality beaches, such as Tourbani and Angelochori, which have received Blue Flag awards.', 'This text provides essential information for visitors to Thessaloniki, Greece, including contact details for the Greek National Tourism Organisation (GNTO) and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. It lists various Greek acronyms relevant to tourists, such as E.O.T. for the GNTO and K.T.E.L. for intercity bus services. The text mentions the use of 220V electric current in Greece and highlights free wireless internet access in public areas. It also details the operating hours and locations of post offices in the city. Emergency phone numbers for police, fire brigade, and medical services are provided, along with contact information for tourist information services.', "Thessaloniki boasts a rich culinary tradition influenced by Byzantine, Ottoman, and various European cuisines, shaped by its multicultural history. The city's gastronomy features traditional tavernas and restaurants that creatively blend local dishes with gourmet elements. Notable delicacies include gyro, souvlaki, patsa, and a variety of seafood dishes. Desserts play a significant role, with popular items like bougatsa, galaktompoureko, and syrupy pastries originating from Istanbul. Koulouri Thessalonikis, a sesame-covered bread, is a common snack sold by street vendors. In winter, locals enjoy salep, a unique hot beverage.", 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, culinary scene, and lively waterfront.', 'The text mentions Thessaloniki and its neighboring areas, but does not provide further details or context.', 'Thessaloniki offers various sports facilities, including an 18-hole golf course at Porto Carras Grand Resort and proximity to several ski centers. Notable ski centers include Seli, Elatochori, 3-5 Pigadia, Lailias, Vora, and Falakro, each with different elevations, runs, and amenities. Information for each ski center, including contact details and websites, is provided. Additional resources for tourists include websites for the Municipality of Thessaloniki, archaeological sites, and weather forecasts.', "The Thessaloniki State Symphony Orchestra, established in 1959, is one of Greece's premier orchestras, performing at the Thessaloniki Concert Hall. The city also offers summer open-air cinemas where films are screened with Greek subtitles. Thessaloniki has a rich sports tradition, hosting major events like the 2004 Olympic Games and various international competitions. Numerous sports facilities are available, including the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium and Poseidonio Sports Centre. The Megas Alexandros International Marathon occurs annually, starting in Ancient Pella and finishing in Thessaloniki. Information on local sports facilities and events can be obtained from the municipality's departments.", 'The text provides a comprehensive overview of Thessaloniki, detailing various church denominations, museums, cultural exhibitions, sports facilities, public transport options, and traditional markets. It lists notable churches such as the Orthodox Metropolitan Church and the Armenian Orthodox Church, alongside museums like the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki and the Jewish Museum. Cultural venues include the Thessaloniki International Trade Fair and several theaters. Sports facilities mentioned include the Alexandreio Sports Arena and various football grounds. Public transport options include a long-distance bus station and a new railway station, while traditional markets like Kapani and Modiano are also highlighted.', "This publication by the Greek National Tourism Organisation, supervised by Angela Varela and coordinated by Eleni Mitraki, features contributions from various professionals including journalist Yannis Ragos and translator Angeliki Christopoulou. It includes photo credits from multiple photographers and is designed by Zoe Tzomentzidou. The publication is not for sale and is available through the Greek National Tourism Organisation's website.", 'Asprovalta and Nea Vrasna beaches offer marine sports and beach volleyball facilities, with Asprovalta beach being 10 km long and awarded a Blue Flag. Stavros is the largest harbor in the area, while the villages of Vrasna and Ano Stavros feature traditional architecture. To reach these locations from Thessaloniki, take bus lines 83, 83M, or 83N to Lagkadas, or travel by coach or car towards Panorama and Kavala. Pikrolimni, located in the Kilkis region, is a shallow lake known for its healing mud with properties three times more concentrated than the Dead Sea. The first Mud-therapy Centre in the Balkans is in nearby Xylokeratia, offering various wellness facilities. Visitors can enjoy mud therapy by the lake in summer, and the center includes a physiotherapy clinic, hotel, restaurant, and sports fields. Pikrolimni is accessible by car or a daily bus from Thessaloniki.', 'The Palace of Galerius is an open-air archaeological museum in the historic center, constructed in the late 3rd to early 4th century. It is part of the Galerian Complex, which included significant structures like the Hippodrome and Rotunda. The palace served as a residence for emperors until its destruction in the 7th century and is a major monument of Late Antiquity. Key features include the Octagon, an audience hall with elaborate decoration; a colonnaded yard; a two-storeyed tank for water collection; a monumental Basilica used for official gatherings; and a bathhouse with various bathing facilities.', "Eptapyrgio, built in the 12th century on an older fortress, features ten towers and remnants of Early Christian walls. The structure underwent modifications by the Ottoman Turks in 1431 and later became a prison in 1890. In 1989, it was transformed into a monument for visitors. Nearby, Palaeologina's Gate, constructed in 1355, leads to Trigoniou Tower, built in the 16th century. This area, known for its breathtaking views, is a popular spot for both locals and tourists.", "Thessaloniki's Old Town, untouched by the 1917 fire, features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architecture. It became populated in the mid-15th century when the Ottomans settled there due to its favorable climate and strategic location. The area retains its original town planning with narrow alleys and squares, attracting artists and students in recent years. Architectural styles include neoclassical and eclectic motifs, particularly in residences of the Dönmeh. Despite modern developments, the Old Town has preserved much of its historical character.", 'The 6th walk along NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE showcases a busy street with impressive late 19th to early 20th-century buildings. Notable sites include Allatini Villa, built in 1898, which served various purposes over the years, including housing the University of Thessaloniki and a military hospital. Casa Bianca, constructed in 1912, features eclectic and art nouveau elements and now hosts a branch of the Municipal Art Gallery. The Nehama Villa, built in 1907, is another significant structure on the avenue. Lastly, the Mordoch Villa, established in 1905, has a rich history, including use as military barracks and a polyclinic, and currently houses the Municipal Art Gallery.', "The Historic Centre, built in 1866 by Sultan Hamid, was originally outside the east walls and restored in 1977 after modifications during the Interwar Period. Aristotle University of Thessaloniki (AUTH) is Greece's first university campus, established on the site of an old Jewish cemetery, with construction starting in 1938 and resuming in the 1950s. The campus features modern architecture by prominent Greek architects and accommodates over 100,000 students, making it the largest in Greece. Notable sites include the Old Building of the Faculty of Philosophy, constructed in 1887, and various museums showcasing ancient sculptures and Byzantine art.", "The Yeni Camii, built in 1902 by architect V. Poselli, served as a mosque for converted Jews and later housed the city's Archaeological Museum. It now functions as a municipal exhibition area with a collection of Roman and Early Christian sculptures. The Hatzimisef Villa, located on Vas. Olgas Ave., was the town's first high school, while the Joseph Modiano villa nearby is currently uninhabited. A bust of King George I, assassinated in 1913, stands at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias Triadas St., crafted by K. Dimitriadis in 1915. The Ivan Hatzimisef Villa, built in 1897, now hosts cultural events and an organic food market. Additionally, the building at 34-36 Evzonon Street features classical, baroque, and renaissance architectural styles.", "Lake Koroneia, also known as Lake Agios Vasileios, has significantly decreased in size and depth due to climate conditions and water resource exploitation. Nea Apollonia, a historic village near Lake Volvi, features mineral springs with therapeutic properties and modern health facilities. Lake Volvi is Greece's second-largest natural lake and a Ramsar site, offering birdwatching and various water sports. The area around Volvi includes tourist attractions and communities like Megali Volvi, Mikri Volvi, and Rentina, which is known for its natural beauty and historical ruins.", "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Greek Highschool built in 1893 and the Transfiguration of Christ Church, established in 1840 on the site of a 1543 chapel. The church features an icon screen depicting the Annunciation, with elements dating back to 1843 and 1943. It also mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (TIF), inaugurated in 1926 and relocated in 1940, which has modern convention centers designed by notable Greek architects. Additionally, the Macedonian Museum of Contemporary Art, established in 1979, is highlighted as Greece's first modern art museum, showcasing modern sculptures and ancient artifacts.", "The historic centre of Thessaloniki features industrial architecture from the late 19th century, including six warehouses built in 1910, which were revamped in 1997 for cultural events. These warehouses now house various institutions such as the International Film Festival, the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, and the Centre of Contemporary Art. The Customs House, built in 1910, serves as the city's passenger board station and showcases early 20th-century French architectural influence. The Ladadika area, spared from the 1917 fire, dates back to the 16th century and was known for its wholesale trade, particularly spices and olive oil. The street layout remains largely unchanged since the late 19th century, with many buildings constructed from industrial brick and wood.", "The Military Museum of the Balkan Wars, located in Gefyra village near Thessaloniki, showcases the area's history with rare relics and authentic furniture from the time of the Greek army's headquarters in 1912. Giannitsa, a modern town with a population of 35,000, features significant Ottoman monuments, including the mausoleum of Gazi Evrenos and the 14th-century hamam. The town is known for its cultural heritage and outdoor activities in nearby green areas. Notable sites include the clock tower and various mosques, reflecting the rich history of the region.", 'Thessaloniki offers a vibrant nightlife with clubs and venues, especially in the summer when many move to open-air locations. Popular areas include Kalamaria and Peraia. The city hosts numerous artistic events year-round, featuring venues like the Thessaloniki Concert Hall and various theaters. Cultural activities include the International Film Festival and the Thessaloniki Book Fair. The Thessaloniki Regency Casino operates 24/7, requiring guests to be 25 or older. Additionally, traditional products like koulouri and trigona Panoramatos are notable in the region.', 'The exhibition showcases Byzantine life, art, and culture from the early to post-Byzantine periods, organized by thematic categories. It includes sections on the Early Christian period, Middle Byzantine period, Late Byzantine period, and Post Byzantine period, each with specific rooms dedicated to various aspects of life and culture. The exhibition also features private collections, including the D. Papastratos Collection with religious art and the D. Oikonomopoulos Collection with a diverse range of artworks. The Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki is mentioned, highlighting its permanent exhibits related to Jewish history.', "The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki displays significant art and artifacts from Macedonia, spanning from prehistoric times to late antiquity. The exhibits are categorized into six sections, including the origins of towns, the evolution of Macedonia from the 7th century BC to late antiquity, and the historical significance of Thessaloniki. Notable displays include exceptional gold craftsmanship from cemeteries, a reconstruction of an archaic temple, and unique items like the Derveni papyrus. The museum highlights the region's rich cultural heritage and its transition through various historical periods.", "Thessaloniki hosts several cultural institutions, including museums and galleries showcasing Greek art. The collection features works by prominent Greek artists, Byzantine icons spanning five centuries, and Greek engravings. The Gallery of the Society for Macedonian Studies is the city's first visual arts museum, displaying 300 pieces from major 20th-century art movements. The Cultural Centre of Thessaloniki organizes exhibitions in collaboration with local agencies, featuring around 250 pieces of various art forms. The Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, established in 1997, highlights the history of Greek cinema through exhibits categorized into six timelines.", "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the remnants of the city's west walls, particularly the Litaia Gate. It highlights the Pasha Hamam, an Ottoman bathhouse built in the 1520s, which was the last of its kind in the area until its closure in 1981. The west of the harbour area saw significant growth in the late 19th century due to the demolition of city walls and the development of industrial units, which have since been transformed into cultural and entertainment venues. Notable sites include the Vilka multi-purpose venue, formerly a textile factory, and the Mylos venue, popular for events. The Moni Lazariston complex houses the State Museum of Contemporary Art, showcasing the area's cultural evolution.", 'The text provides contact information and websites for various museums and cultural institutions in Thessaloniki, including the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, Museum of Photography, Olympic Museum, and more. It lists their addresses, telephone numbers, and websites, facilitating access to cultural resources. Additionally, it mentions a collaboration among five museums in Thessaloniki aimed at promoting cultural activities and organizing exhibitions. This collaboration includes the Archaeological Museum, Museum of Byzantine Culture, State Museum of Contemporary Art, Macedonian Museum of Modern Art, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art.', 'The text describes various historical and architectural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Jewish Museum housed in a 1904 building, Venizelou Street known for its eclectic and art deco styles, and the Pazar (Yahudi) Hamami, a 16th-century bathhouse. It highlights the architectural significance of the Gategno-Florentin Building and the Chamber of Commerce & Industry, showcasing neoclassical design. The area is also noted for its vibrant marketplace, including an open-air flower market known as Louloudadika.', 'The text describes two significant Byzantine monuments in the city. The first is the Moni Latomou, an early cross-in-square domed church from the 5th or 6th century, notable for its ceiling mosaics depicting the Vision of Ezekiel and a minaret entrance from its later conversion to a mosque. The second is Moni Vlatadon, the only active Byzantine monastery in the city, founded in the 14th century, featuring a unique church structure and significant murals from the 14th and 17th centuries. It also has a large garden with views of the city and additional facilities like a library and a bookstore.', 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire.', 'The text describes the historical development of the area known as Nea Paralia in Thessaloniki, which began to grow in the late 19th century after the demolition of city walls and the introduction of tramways. Initially named Exoches due to its rural character, it became a luxury residential area with diverse nationalities coexisting. However, from the 1930s, the area declined and transformed into a typical urban setting by the 1960s. Today, Nea Paralia stretches along Megalou Alexandrou Avenue and is popular for leisure activities, offering scenic views of the Thermaic Gulf and Mount Olympus, especially at sunset. Notable landmarks include the statue of Alexander the Great and the artistic installation of umbrellas by N. Zongolopoulos.', "Thessaloniki, an early center of Christianity, was significant during the Byzantine period, housing numerous Christian monuments and churches. These structures, built between the 4th and 15th centuries, have been recognized as UNESCO World Heritage Monuments since 1988. The Holy Twelve Apostles Church, one of the oldest, was constructed between 1310 and 1314 and served as the main church of a monastery. The church features murals and iconography depicting the life of the Holy Virgin. A tour of Thessaloniki's Byzantine monuments offers a unique experience, showcasing the city's rich historical and cultural heritage.", 'The text describes various notable locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki. Tsitsani Square features a bust of composer V. Tsitsanis and is surrounded by well-tended houses. Eptapyrgiou Street runs along the northern city walls, showcasing traditional buildings and the old Zihne Camii mosque. Moni Vlatadon is mentioned as a point of interest. Portara is one of the main gates of the northern city walls, adorned with ceramics and inscriptions. The Acropolis, specifically Eptapyrgio (Yedi Kule), is highlighted as a significant fortified area within the city walls. The area is popular among both residents and tourists.', 'The text provides information about various churches in Thessaloniki, including their addresses and contact numbers. It also highlights cultural events such as Demetria, an autumn festival featuring theatrical and musical performances, and the Thessaloniki International Film Festival, which has been held since 1960 and showcases films from various sections. Additionally, it mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.), a significant trade fair in the Balkans that has been taking place since 1926, presenting Greek industry and entrepreneurship. Contact information for cultural offices and event organizations is also included.', "Thessaloniki was founded in 315 BC by Cassander, named after his wife, and became a significant city under Roman control by 168 BC. It served as the capital of the Roman province of Macedonia by 148 BC and was connected to the wider world through the Via Egnatia around 130 BC. The city was declared a 'free town' in 42 BC and hosted Apostle Paul's visits. In the late 3rd to early 4th century AD, it became the seat of the eastern Roman Empire under Galerius. The city faced various raids but was protected by its walls. It experienced a golden age from 1300 to 1430, marked by cultural and economic growth. Thessaloniki changed hands multiple times, falling to the Venetians in 1423 and the Ottoman Turks in 1430, while also having a significant Jewish population in the 15th century."]
response: The historical and cultural significances of various landmarks and neighborhoods in Thessaloniki are substantial, with the city boasting a rich heritage dating back to the Byzantine period. The traditional commercial areas, such as the Historic Centre (1) and (2), are considered privileged places, with many well-known shops, green spots, and cultural institutions. Notable museums, like the Archaeological Museum and the Museum of Byzantine Culture, house significant collections and host periodic exhibitions, events, and educational programs. The UNESCO Byzantine Monuments, including the Holy Twelve Apostles Church and the Moni Latomou, demonstrate the city's importance in the Byzantine world and its influence on the entire Byzantine world. Overall, the city's historical and cultural significance is reflected in its well-preserved and restored landmarks, museums, and cultural institutions, which are a testament to its rich heritage.
reference: The historical and cultural significances of various landmarks and neighborhoods in Thessaloniki, particularly traditional commercial areas, notable museums, and UNESCO Byzantine Monuments, reflect a rich tapestry of influences and transformations over time. Traditional commercial areas like Vlali Square and Bezesteni highlight the city's vibrant market culture, while notable museums such as the Archaeological Museum and the Museum of Byzantine Culture showcase its artistic heritage. The UNESCO-listed Byzantine monuments, including Agios Dimitrios Church and Acheiropoietos Church, emphasize the city's historical importance and architectural beauty, making Thessaloniki a unique blend of history and modernity.

3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
The area is considered  
as one of the most privileged 
places downtown on account 
of its proximity to the beach;  
it is traditionally regarded as 
the residential area of the 
well-to-do. There are many 
well-known shops here, green 
spots, as well as some of the 
most important museums  
and cultural institutions.
1 	\x07
THE WHITE TOWER 
AREA
This central location is where 
major city roads meet (Nikis 
Ave, Megalou Alexandrou Ave., 
Pavlou Mela, Ethnikis Amynis, 
Germanou) and where the old 
part of the waterfront meets 
the new one. It affords a lovely 
view of the sea; there are 
green areas and many shops, 
cafés and bars.
MUST SEE:
1.1  The White Tower.
This is the city’s most 
famous landmark - 
monument.', '22
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
aisled post-byzantine basilica. 
The interior decoration is of 
particular interest as it shows 
influences from baroque, 
rococo and neoclassical styles.
6.3  The Jewish Museum 
of Thessaloniki.
It is housed in a 1904 historic 
building (V. Poselli), which 
survived the 1917 fire and is 
owned by Jews. There used to 
be a shopping arcade there, 
once, and it has –at times- 
housed a bank and the offices 
of a jewish newspaper (for 
museum exhibits, see p. 73).
6.4  Venizelou street. 
A very busy street linking 
Eleftherias sq. with the 
Residency since 1867 (see p. 39). 
It is a shopping street lined 
with many interesting buildings 
of eclectic and art deco style, 
mostly up to Egnatia street 
(see p. 34). On the north side 
of the junction of Venizelou 
and Tsimiski streets, lies the 
Gategno-Florentin Building, a 
typical example of architectural 
eclecticism, built in 1925, by 
civil engineer J.J. Pleyber. It is 
a four-floor building and fronts 
three streets. 
6.5  Pazar (Yahudi) Hamami.', 'Notice the glass globe on 
the top of the building, a point 
of reference in Eleftherias Sq. 
In the neighbouring Komninon 
Street it is worth noticing the 
eclectic style on buildings 
such as Luxemburg Hotel as 
well as Tourist and Excelsior 
Hotels at the junction with 
Mitropoleos streets.
4 	PORT
The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth. 
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE', '26
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
quarter covers the area around 
the junction of Tsimiski and 
Pavlou Mela streets. It was 
named after the diagonal 
tracing of P. Mela street.
1.5  YMCA Building.
This emblematic building 
(1934) houses the Young 
Men’s Christian Association 
of Thessaloniki. It bears a 
significant mixture of elements 
of neo-colonial and byzantine 
architecture. The building also 
houses Avlaia theatre; among 
the surrounding constructions 
are an outdoor basketball field 
and a tennis court, an indoor 
gym and a cultural centre.  
In front of the building lies  
the small YMCA square.  
The Armenian Church (1903, 
V. Poselli) is at a very short 
distance, between Dialetti  
and Ant. Kamara Streets.
1.6  Archaeological 
Museum.
It was designed by P. 
Karantinos, a major Greek 
architect, and it was 
inaugurated in 1962. Inspired 
by the ancient Greek Revival 
Architectural style, it is 
considered as one of the most 
typical examples of modernist 
architectural design in Greece. 
An annex was added in 1980 
and in 2003 the museum  
was extensively remodelled  
to accommodate contemporary 
needs. There are rooms for 
periodic exhibitions, events 
and educational programmes, 
a café and a shop (see p.70  
for museum exhibits).', '20
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
Construction for the first 
wharf of the port began in 
the late 19th c.; in 1910 six 
warehouses were built and 
all of them are fine examples 
of industrial architecture of 
that time. In 1997, on the 
occasion of events celebrating 
Thessaloniki as the European 
Capital of Culture, five of them 
were revamped and reopened: 
warehouses 1 and D housed 
the International Film Festival 
of Thessaloniki (see p. 
108); warehouse A houses 
the Thessaloniki Cinema 
Museum and the Museum of 
Photography of Thessaloniki 
(to view the exhibits, see p. 
77-78); warehouse B1 houses 
the Thessaloniki Centre of 
Contemporary Art (see p. 75); 
and warehouse C is now  
a bar-restaurant. This place  
is among the most popular 
ones for strolling, relaxing,  
and enjoying a fine view  
of the seafront. 
MUST SEE:
4.1  Customs House 
(Passenger Board).
This imposing 200 m. long 
building was built in 1910, 
designed by architect Eli 
Modiano, and its structure 
bears the influence of early 
20th c. french architecture.  
Since 1987 it is the city port’s 
passenger board station.
5 	LADADIKA
This is one of the very few 
main town areas that were 
spared destruction when 
the 1917 fire broke out.', '5
