7', '15
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community.', '4 	ROMFEI SQUARE
This is Ano Poli’s central 
square. To reach it, take 
Theofilou Street where 
the neoclassical building 
housing the Vice-Mayor’s 
office for Culture is located. 
In the square, you will see a 
Byzantine bath-house known 
as Koule Kafe (see p. 12); the 
entire area has been named 
after it. On the NE side of the 
square (7, Krispou st.) you 
will notice the architectural 
masterpiece of a 19th c. 
neoclassical building which 
houses the municipal Library of 
Ano Poli. On Theotokopoulou 
Street, near the square lies 
the 14th c. Byzantine church 
of the Taxiarchs [Archangels] 
which used to be a monastery 
katholikon [main church] and 
has undergone later changes.
5 	\x07HOSIOS [VENERABLE] 
DAVID Church
(Moni Latomou, see p. 13)
44
45', '14
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
9 	\x07
AGIA AIKATERINI  
[St. CATHERINE’s] 
CHURCH
This 14th c. Byzantine church is 
situated in the centre of Agia 
Aikaterini town quarter in Ano 
Poli [Upper City] area (see p. 
42) It is a complex tetrastyle 
inscribed cross-in-square 
five-domed church with an 
ambulatory. It bears an elaborate 
brick-work on the external 
surfaces and outstanding 
murals, contemporary to the 
construction of the edifice, 
which depict figures of saints, 
scenes from the Gospel, 
miracles of Christ etc. During 
the Ottoman Rule the church 
was converted into a mosque 
(Yakup Pasha Camii) and the 
murals were covered in plaster, 
to be exposed once again during 
the restoration works that took 
place in 1947 – 1951.
10	\x07PROFITIS ILIAS 
[PROPHET ELIJAH] 
CHURCH
This imposing church (late 13th 
– mid 14th c.) towering over 
Olympiados st. in the outskirts 
of Ano Poli (see p. 42) is 
thought to have been the 
main church of Nea Moni [New 
Monastery] or Moni Akapniou 
[Akapniou Monastery].', '13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.
8', '11
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
portal to the southwest and 
the cistern to the northwest. 
It is a complex tetrastyle 
cross-in-square church with 
a narthex and a peristyle on 
the three sides and extremely 
symmetrical proportions. 
When it was converted into 
a mosque, during the Turkish 
rule, the murals and mosaics – 
outstanding specimens  
of Palaeologan art dating  
to the 14th c. – were covered  
by plaster and a minaret was 
added to the southwestern side.
2 	
\x07PANAGIA CHALKEON 
CHURCH
It is located on the SW side 
of Dikastirion Sq. [Law Courts 
Sq.]. It was built in 1128 on 
the site of an ancient temple 
of Hephaestus or Kaveiros.  
It is a representative specimen 
of the architecture of the 
“School of Constantinople” and 
was thus named because of 
the area it was built on, known 
as the district of coppersmiths 
(masters of copper – chalkos). 
The most prominent feature 
is the level above the narthex. 
In 1430 it was converted into 
a mosque and was named 
Kazancilar Camii.
3 	\x07
ACHEIROPOIITOS 
CHURCH
It was founded in the second 
half of the 5th c. on the site 
of the roman public baths 
and it was dedicated to 
Panagia (Virgin Mary).', '13
1st walk:

other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the

7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '12
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Christian monuments in the 
Orthodox world. It is a cross-
domed basilica and used to 
be the Metropolitan Church 
(Cathedral) until 1523 when it 
was converted into a mosque; 
it was restored to Christian 
worship after 1912. The 
capitals date to the 5th – 6th 
c. (they were part of the older 
church); the wonderful mosaics 
are an absolute must-see, 
particularly the ones on the

Ascension of Christ, as are

side, amid green surroundings

from this point you will enter 
the early-Christian baptistery

5 	\x07TRANSFIGURATION OF 
THE SAVIOUR CHURCH 
[METAMORFOSI SOTIROS]
It is located on Egnatia Street

link the town’s civic centre

It starts at the harbour from

and it is known as Palia Paralia

Construction took place possibly

6 	ROTUNDA [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church

with their variety of themes,

Georgios [St. George] whence

4.

reference_contexts:
['1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
During the Ottoman period it 
was named Kule Hamam and 
was divided in two (male and 
female section).
12 	\x07HOSIOS DAVID  
(MONI LATOMOU)
Moni Latomou [Latomou 
Monastery] has a huge 
archaeological and historical 
value, since it is an early type 
of a cross-in-square domed 
church. Its construction dates 
back to the 5th or 6th c. and 
it is believed to have been 
built by Theodora, daughter 
of the Byzantine emperor 
Maximilianus, who had been 
baptised a Christian. The 
monastery was dedicated to 
Hosios David [Saint David] in 
1921. Especially noteworthy 
are the mosaic depictions 
on the ceiling which show 
the Vision of Ezekiel and 
are contemporary to the 
construction of the monastery; 
the later ones of the 12th, 13th 
and 14th c. are also great art 
specimens of the Komnenian 
period. There is a surviving 
minaret entrance built in the 
16th c. when the church was 
converted into a mosque. The 
small picturesque yard offers 
an unobstructed view of the 
city and the Thermaic gulf.
13 	MONI VLATADON
It is the only Byzantine 
monastery in the city with 
an active community. It was 
founded in the 14th c. by the 
monks Vlatis (or Vlateus) 
brothers and was dedicated to 
Pantocrator Christos [Almighty 
Christ]. Celebrations take 
place on the Transfiguration 
of Christ feast day. Its main 
church [katholikon] is of the 
inscribed cross-in-square type 
but the dome rests on the 
walls and on two piers instead 
of columns. It is surrounded 
by a portico and there are two 
chapels. Murals were painted 
during 1360 – 1380 and the 
17th c. iconostasis is particularly 
noteworthy. It is surrounded 
by a large garden offering a 
wonderful view of the city and 
there is also a small peacock 
farm; in the grounds you will 
also find the newer buildings 
of Misirogleios Library, the 
Patriarchal Foundation for 
Theological Studies (1968),  
a space provided for the study of 
pictorial manuscripts from Mount 
Athos, a bookstore and a shop.
8
']
response:
A cross-in-square domed church has the following architectural features: 
- A square shape 
- A domed structure 
- A portico or surrounding area 
- Often, chapels or a narthex at the corners. 
These features are exemplified in the Moni Latomou, which is a cross-in-square domed church with a square shape, a domed structure, a portico, and chapels.
Note: The original answer did not include the portico or surrounding area, which is now included.
reference: A cross-in-square domed church, as exemplified by the Moni Latomou, is defined by its early construction dating back to the 5th or 6th century, featuring a dome that rests on the walls and is surrounded by an inscribed cross layout.

1 	EGNATIA STREET
This central avenue has 
been there practically since 
Thessaloniki’s founding,  
as it is a section of the road 
constructed by the Romans  
in the 2nd c. BC, and connected 
Dyrrhachium (Durrës, in 
modern day Albania) with 
Constantinople. It starts at 
Dimokratia square (see p. 58) 
and ends at the TIF grounds 
(see p. 31) and the Aristotle 
University of Thessaloniki, 
splitting in two the town’s 
historic centre. It is a busy 
shopping area with numerous 
remarkable buildings of 
eclectic and art deco style 
dating to the early 20th c. 
(mostly old hotels) that are 
absolutely worth observing,  
as well as some of the city’s 
most important monuments.

after G. Colombo, an Italian 
who opened a hotel there  
in the early 20th century. This 
is the location of Kolomvou 
Archway (31, Egnatia St.) 
which has become a leisure 
hub with cafés, bars and 
restaurants inside.
1.2  Hamza Bey Mosque.
It was built in 1467 by the 
daughter of Hamza Bey, the 
military commander of Sultan 
Murad II.']

response: The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki holds significant architectural importance in Greece due to its modernist design and its status as the first University Campus in Greece to be built following complete architectural plans. The campus features several notable buildings, including the main Administration Buildings, the School of Chemistry, the School of Law, the School of Theology, and the two buildings of the Main Library. These buildings form a major ensemble of modern architecture and are considered a notable example of modernist architectural design in Greece. Additionally, the university's campus is home to the Teloglion Foundation of Art AUTh, which houses an extensive collection of art and features a unique architectural design. Overall, the Aristotle University of Thessaloniki is a prominent example of modernist architecture in Greece and a significant cultural and educational institution. The campus is also notable for its connection to the city's historic center, as it splits Egnatia Street into two, and is surrounded by other significant buildings and monuments, such as the Hamza Bey Mosque and the Kolomvou Archway.
reference: The Aristotle University of Thessaloniki holds architectural significance as the first university campus in Greece built following complete architectural plans, featuring a major ensemble of modern architecture designed by leading Greek architects.

 16th-18th c.:	
Thessaloniki grows,

 1917:

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

of the avenue is lined with

the opposite wide pedestrian

Thessaloniki’s relatively

Thessaloniki Wines.

GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc).']

The museum also features a collection of corkscrews and wine-making equipment. Thessaloniki lies in the 
centre of a wide area that is 
extremely interesting from  
an archaeological, historical 
and natural point of view; 
there are countless options for 
outdoor activities, relaxing and 
entertainment. For instance, 
you can combine your stay 
in town with a day excursion 
to renowned archaeological 
sites and places of historical 
interest, to fascinating towns 
and great natural reserves  
or to areas offering recreation 
or relaxation.
1
	
ANCIENT PELLA
Inhabited since the Late 
Helladic period, the area 
flourished when Archelaos,  
the Macedon king, moved  
the capital of the Macedonian 
state from Aiges (Vergina) to 
Pella (late 5th – early 4th c. BC). 
The then seaside town grew 
larger during the reign of King 
Philip II (his son, Alexander 
the Great, was born here) 
and grew even larger later 
during the rule of Cassander. 
By the mid-2nd century BC it 
had evolved into the greatest 
political, financial and cultural 
centre among the Hellenic City 
States. In 168 BC when the 
Macedonians were defeated in 
the battle of Pydna, Pella was 
conquered by the Romans. 
It gradually declined and got 
eventually deserted in the 1st 
century BC. Among the finds 
of the greatest value are the 
exquisite mosaic floors in the 
buildings, which manifest the 
high standard of living enjoyed 
by the residents.

112', 'On Good Friday afternoon every 
church prepares the Epitaphios 
which is an embroidered cloth 
icon of Christ prepared for burial, 
lying on a low table adorned with 
flowers. Later in the evening, 
Epitaphios is placed at the head of 
a procession and it is followed by 
the church congregation; people 
hold lit candles and chant as they 
walk the streets of their town or 
village – this happens throughout 
the country on Good Friday.
• Resurrection of Christ: Mass 
is celebrated at midnight before 
Easter Sunday with fireworks and 
burning candles.
• Easter Sunday: It is 
customary for Greeks to have 
a meal of lamb roasted on the 
spit, that day. Celebrations 
include singing and dancing 
throughout the entire day.
• May 1st (Labour Day): 
Flower festivals take place in 
Thessaloniki. 
• Dormition of Theotokos 
[Mother of God]: 
August 15th. 
• October 26th – 28th: 
A three-day celebration 
commemorating the liberation 
of the city from the Turkish rule, 
and a religious feast in honour 
of Saint Demetrius [Agios 
Dimitrios], the patron saint of 
the city, on October 26th. A 
military parade takes place on 
October 28th to commemorate 
the beginning of Greek 
participation in World War II.
• Christmas:  
December 25th – 26th.
OTHER TRADITIONAL 
FESTIVALS
• Carnival: Carnival events last 
for 3 weeks and end on Shrove 
Monday.']

(3, Vas. Olgas Ave.)
This is yet another building 
typical of the style found in 
the area, housing the town’s 
1st High School. At no. 5, lies 
the Joseph Modiano villa, 
today uninhabited and barely 
discernible behind the fencing. 
A branch of the town’s 1st High 
School was once located here.
']

user_input: What historical significance does Ethnikis Amynis Street hold in relation to the development of Thessaloniki?

['1.3  Ethnikis Amynis 
Street.
It leads from the White 
Tower to Syntrivaniou Square 
(see p. 37) and to Agiou 
Dimitriou Street (see p. 39). 
It was laid out after the 1889 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls (a section of its 
Byzantine ramparts still stands 
on Filikis Etaireias Street which 
runs parallel to Ethnikis Amynis 
Street. Until 1912 it was called 
Hamidiye Boulevard, in honour 
of the Sultan Abdul Hamid 
II, as all the buildings along 
the street were his property. 
Today, this is the location of 
the Theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (1962, 
V. Kassandras) housing the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G.) as well as  
the Gallery of the S.M.S. (see p. 
77), and the adjacent Building 
A’ of the S.M.S. (1951, A. 
Nikolopoulos), the Hellenic 
Army Club (1953, P. Mylonas) 
and Alexandros cinema. The 
small Tsirogiannis Park is 
situated nearby and around 
it you will find some popular 
cafés and bars. 
1.4  Diagonios.
This typical downtown 
22', '25

various names; in the 19th 
c. it was called Tower of the 
Janissaries or Blood Tower  
as it served as jail for 
prisoners on death row 
whose life was eventually 
taken by the Janissaries on 
the ramparts. In 1890 it was 
painted white thus acquiring 
its current name. A particularly 
interesting exhibition is held 
in the Tower on the history 
of Thessaloniki (see p. 73); 
from the top of the Tower 
you can enjoy the panoramic 
view. The small square around 
the monument is one of the 
hotspots in town; this is where 
small boat bars leave for a 
short run within the Thermaic 
Gulf, serving coffee or a drink. 
Opposite lies the Park of the 
White Tower where you will 
find the open air Municipal 
Garden Theatre,  
a bar, a playground and  
a skate spot.
1.2  Royal [Vasiliko] 
Theatre.
It was built in 1940, got 
renovated in 1996, and it has 
a seating capacity of 800. 
This is one of the winter halls 
(Melina Merkouri Hall) of the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G., see p. 110).

It leads from the White

(see p. 37) and to Agiou

The area is one of the biggest 
ports of the country and of the 
southeastern Mediterranean, 
with a significant trade and 
passenger traffic. This is where 
the first artificial harbour of 
the town was constructed by 
Constantine the Great during 
his short stay in Thessaloniki 
(322-323 AD); later on during 
the Turkish Occupation it 
was banked up with earth.

Thessaloniki’s Old Town is 
full of atmosphere. It covers 
the area in between the city

the south), and has had the 
luck to remain untouched by 
the 1917 great fire. It was 
virtually uninhabited until

it was conquered by the 
Ottomans who selected it for 
settlement on account of its

and strategic position. The 
two and three-storey houses 
bear mixed Macedonian

in turkish]; there are also 
residences with neoclassical 
and eclectic style motifs 
where the Dönmeh lived, i.e. 
converts to Islam who secretly 
remained Jews. After 1922 
many refugees settled in the 
area. Despite the construction

recent decades, it has kept 
its original town planning, to 
a large extent, with narrow 
alleys and scant squares, as 
well as its original architectural 
features, particularly in the 
west and east part of the town.

and the various ethnic and 
religious communities live  
in harmony. In the 18th c.  
the town acquires the features  
of a large trade centre.
 Late 19th c.:	
A railway connection is 
established with Europe and 
Constantinople. Infrastructure 
gets streamlined and 
Thessaloniki acquires the feel 
of a cosmopolitan European 
city. The Greeks become at 
this point in time the largest 
part of the population.
 1890:	
Fire incinerates a considerable 
part of the town’s seafront 
zone.
 1912:	
During the 1st Balkan War, 
the Greek army seizes the 
town on October 26th; after 
five centuries of ottoman 
occupation, Thessaloniki 
becomes part of Greece.
 1916:	
Following a clash with 
King Constantine, Eleftherios 
Venizelos forms the 
temporary “National Defence 
Government” in Thessaloniki, 
which remained there for 
several months.
 1917:	
The biggest part of the 
town is destroyed by a fire 
that breaks out on August 
18th and lasts for 32 hours.', '40
4th walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (3)
3.3  Yeni Hamam (Aigli).
It was built in 1531 on the 
site of a roman or byzantine 
bath. Only 1/3 of the building 
remains, and the two domed 
halls were joined into one in the 
20th c., given that until 1944-45 
it was used as a bathing place 
for males and females. It is 
known as Aigli, the name it had 
when it was a cinema and later 
a multi-purpose hall. 
3.4  Alaca Imaret.
It was built in 1484, according 
to an inscription located above 
the main entrance. Named after 
a poorhouse (imaret in turkish) 
located on the grounds, it 
featured a minaret adorned with 
multi-coloured (alaca in turkish) 
stones, the only remaining part 
of which is the base. Surrounded 
by tall blocks of flats in recent 
years, this imposing building  
is an example of symmetric, 
skilled masonry and includes  
a central hall with two rounded 
domes and an arcade covered 
with five cupolas. Occasionally, 
it becomes the venue for 
exhibitions and cultural events.
3.5  Profitis Ilias [Prophet 
Elijah] Church 
(see p. 12)
3.6  Panagia Lagoudiani 
Church (Virgin Mary Guiding 
All Men).
This small three-aisled 
Byzantine basilica is located 
on the outskirts of Ano Poli.', '23
2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
warehouses in Thessaloniki see 
also p. 62). To change it into 
a shopping mall (Plateia) in 
1995-1997, it was completely 
reshaped with only the exterior 
remaining unchanged. Today it 
houses shops, cinemas, cafés 
and restaurants, all of which 
surround the central atrium.
6.8  Buildings on Karolou 
Dil [Charles Diehl] street.
At the junction of Tsimiski 
and Karolou Dil Streets lie 
impressive buildings that 
date to the early 20th c., now 
housing shops and offices; 
they are absolutely worth your 
attention. 
7 	\x07TRADITIONAL 
MARKETS
The area west of Aristotelous 
street and south of Egnatia 
Street encompasses the 
town’s traditional market; it 
is dotted with small shops, 
malls and arcades, most of 
which date back to the time 
of the Turkish Occupation. 
Today, in these much visited 
marketplaces, you can find all 
kinds of products – food and 
spices, fabrics, jewellery, small 
boutiques and also tavernas, 
ouzo restaurants and coffee 
shops.
MUST SEE:
7.1  Modiano Market.
It was built in 1922 by 
engineer E. Modiano, and it is 
known as Modiano Market. It 
is a glass-roofed rectangular 
edifice containing 140 food 
shops inside its three arcades.']
reference_contexts:
['30
3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
flats facing the adjacent 
Ippodromiou square. This was 
a 450 m. long and a 95 m. 
wide structure and it used to 
be the centre of social activity 
for citizens until 390 AD, 
when emperor Theodosius 
ordered the massacre of 
7,000 Thessalonians there; 
the event led to the close-
down of the Hippodrome. It is 
worth visiting the Thessaloniki 
History Centre, situated in the 
square’s south side as well as 
the remarkable 18th c. Agios 
Antonios church in Margariti 
street nearby. 
8.7  Arched Hall.
It lies at the intersection  
of Gounari and Svolou streets. 
This was a place with heating 
installations for holding 
symposia and ceremonies. 
It had a direct access to 
the imperial box in the 
Hippodrome.
8.8  Theatre - stadium  
in Apellou Street.
The remains of a building 
have been located at 5 & 
7 Apellou St., and they are 
considered to have been part 
of the theatre-stadium of the 
town, which was in use from 
the 1st until the 4th c. AD.  
There are references connecting 
this place with the martyrdom 
of Agios Dimitrios, the city’s 
patron saint.
9 	THREE CHURCHES
On the south side of Egnatia 
Street, between K. Palaiologou 
St. (to the west) and Agapinou 
St. (to the east) there are three 
interesting churches at a short 
distance from each other that 
are definitely worth visiting.
MUST SEE:
9.1  Panagouda Church 
(Panagia Gorgoepikoos
– Our Lady Quick to Hear)- 
also called the Church of Mikri 
Panagia. This building (1818) 
was erected on the spot of an 
older church destroyed by fire 
in 1789, and it was located at 
the heart of the city’s Greek 
quarters during the Turkish 
Occupation. According to 12th 
- 14th c. historical references, 
this used to be the location 
of the Monastery of Panagia 
Gorgoepikoos and it is still 
known by that name. Next 
to it you will see the historic 
neoclassical building of the 
28.  
The 
Macedonian 
Museum of 
Contemporary 
Art.
29.  
View of the 
Thessaloniki 
International 
Trade Fair 
facilities.
30.  
The OTE Tower 
commanding 
the city.
28
']
response: According to the text, Panagouda Church (also known as the Panagia Gorgoepikoos – Our Lady Quick to Hear) was erected in 1818 on the site of an older church destroyed by fire in 1789. During the Turkish Occupation, it was used as a mosque, known as Ishakiye Camii (the mosque of Isaac). The church still retains some murals from the 13th-14th centuries depicting saints and prelates, including the Virgin Mary. Therefore, Panagouda Church holds historical significance as a site of worship during the Turkish Occupation and a remnant of the city's Byzantine heritage.
reference: Panagouda Church holds historical significance as it was erected on the site of an older church destroyed by fire in 1789, located in the heart of the city's Greek quarters during the Turkish Occupation, and is associated with the Monastery of Panagia Gorgoepikoos.

GENERAL FACTS
Greece is on Europe’s southeast 
end with a population of 
10,788,000. It is a parliamentary 
republic and a member of the 
European Union since 1981. 
Thessaloniki is located 510 
km N of Athens. It is the second 
biggest city in the country and the 
biggest in Northern Greece; it is 
also the capital of the Thessaloniki 
Regional Unit as well as of the 
Region of Central Macedonia. 
It is situated within the inlet of 
the Thermaic Gulf and the city 
population is over 1 million.
Currency. Since January 1st 2001 
the euro is the Greek national 
currency. You can change money

offices, or in banks.  
Calling code. The international

Time. Greece is seven hours 
ahead of the Eastern Standard 
Time, two hours ahead of 
Greenwich Mean Time and 
one hour ahead of the Central

2nd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (1)
TRADITIONAL COMMERCIAL CENTRE
WWII the area was gradually 
downgraded; in 1985 it was 
proclaimed a historic area with 
listed buildings. Since the early 
1990s, steps were taken to 
upgrade Ladadika, turning it 
into a hotspot area in town 
with numerous restaurants, 
clubs, cafés and venues where 
live Greek music is performed. 
A central spot where you can 
start your tour is Morichovou 
sq.; it is worth stopping by 
Petrakaki sq. where you will see 
the Mansion of the Ottoman 
Post Office (today a hotel) 
–among other sights. Other 
places of interest are Aigyptou, 
Katouni, Lykourgou, and Edessis 
streets (in Emporiou sq. or 
Ano Ladadika, past Tsimiski 
street) where you will see two 
surviving inns. There are still 
traces of smoke dating to 
the 1917 fire on the facades 
of buildings fronting on the 
harbour!
6 	TSIMISKI STREET
This main street is among the 
busiest downtown places and 
connects YMCA square (see 
p. 26) with Ladadika.', '88
DAY EXCURSIONS
Jewish quarter in Europe, 
which maintains a traditional 
character in its entirety. It 
is worth taking a walk and 
visiting the Roman, Ottoman 
and Industrial age monuments 
in the traditional districts of 
Kyriotissa, Panagia Dexia, and 
Makariotissa; you can also visit 
the Public Central Library which 
has earned an international 
award, or relax in the parks  
and squares.
How to get there.  
Vergina is about 63 km SW  
of Thessaloniki. If you travel by 
car, follow the signs to Veroia 
and after that to Vergina. You 
can also take the intercity bus 
or the train to reach Veroia  
and then take the local bus  
to Vergina.
3 	DION
This most enchanting 
archaeological site is  
located under the imposing 
Olympus mountain range, in  
a 150-hectare green area amid 
flowing waters coming from 
Vafyras River and from other 
springs; it is the habitat of 
many species of birds, reptiles 
and amphibians. This used to 
be a sacred place to ancient 
Macedonians who worshipped 
Olympian Zeus and the Muses 
[daughters of Zeus] here.']

response: The Customs House building was designed by architect Eli Modiano and its structure bears the influence of early 20th c. French architecture.  The building is a 2-storeyed structure and is located in the heart of Thessaloniki, Greece.  It serves as the passenger board station and is a notable example of modern Greek architecture.  The building's design is characterized by its use of stone and its classical elements, which are reminiscent of French architecture of the time.  The Customs House building is a popular tourist destination and is known for its unique blend of modern and traditional architectural styles.
reference: The Customs House, designed by architect Eli Modiano in 1910, shows influences of early 20th century French architecture.

3rd walk: 
HISTORIC CENTRE (2)
MUSEUM AREA
flats facing the adjacent 
Ippodromiou square. This was 
a 450 m. long and a 95 m. 
wide structure and it used to 
be the centre of social activity 
for citizens until 390 AD, 
when emperor Theodosius 
ordered the massacre of 
7,000 Thessalonians there; 
the event led to the close-
down of the Hippodrome. It is 
worth visiting the Thessaloniki 
History Centre, situated in the 
square’s south side as well as 
the remarkable 18th c. Agios 
Antonios church in Margariti 
street nearby. 
8.7  Arched Hall.
It lies at the intersection  
of Gounari and Svolou streets. 
This was a place with heating 
installations for holding 
symposia and ceremonies. 
It had a direct access to 
the imperial box in the 
Hippodrome.
8.8  Theatre - stadium  
in Apellou Street.
The remains of a building 
have been located at 5 & 
7 Apellou St., and they are 
considered to have been part 
of the theatre-stadium of the 
town, which was in use from 
the 1st until the 4th c. AD.  
There are references connecting 
this place with the martyrdom 
of Agios Dimitrios, the city’s 
patron saint.
9 	THREE CHURCHES
On the south side of Egnatia 
Street, between K. Palaiologou 
St.', '70
ARCHAEOLOGICAL MUSEUM 
OF THESSALONIKI
Works of art of outstanding 
value and excavated ensembles 
from the entire region of 
Macedonia are on display, 
covering all the aspects of 
private and public life in the 
area, from the prehistoric era 
to the late antiquity period. 
Exhibits are organised in six 
basic categories:
• Towards the birth of towns. 
(ground floor, room 4). The 
evidence on display shows 
that there were settlements in 
Macedonia dating to the Iron 
Age, from 1100 to 700 BC.
• Macedonia from the 7th c.  
BC until Late Antiquity. 
(ground floor, room 5). Eight 
large theme sections cover 
various aspects of private 
and public life in Macedonia 
from the archaic years, when 
the independent Macedonian 
kingdom was created, until 
the 1st – 4th c. AD, when the 
entire region was a province 
of the Roman Empire. Finds 
come mainly from excavations 
carried out in areas of central 
Macedonia.
• Thessaloniki, Metropolis 
of Macedonia. (ground 
floor, room 6). Historical and 
archaeological information 
is presented, starting from 
315 BC when the town was 
founded. There is also a 
partial reconstruction of an 
archaic temple of Ionic order, 
whose original position is yet 
unknown; it was transported 
to the area of the Temples of 
Thessaloniki during the Roman 
occupation.']

response:
The Ataturk Museum, located in Thessaloniki, Greece, holds significant historical importance as it was the residence of Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey. Although not directly related to Ataturk's life in Turkey, the museum provides a glimpse into his life and legacy in Greece. The museum's courtyard features exhibits showcasing Ataturk's legacy, including a café with an atmospheric setting. The museum is part of the larger historical significance of Thessaloniki, a city with a rich history dating back to the 1st century BC, and is home to the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki, which features exhibits on the history of the region, including the ancient city of Thessaloniki and its connection to the Roman Empire. Overall, the Ataturk Museum serves as a unique historical site, offering insights into Ataturk's life and the history of modern Turkey, as well as the broader historical context of Thessaloniki and the region of Macedonia.
The final answer is: The Ataturk Museum holds significant historical importance as it was the residence of Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey.
reference: The Ataturk Museum holds historical significance as it was the house of Kemal Ataturk, the founder of modern Turkey, and features a pomegranate tree planted by his father.

GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes.

(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc),

Greece Cultural Foundation 
[M.I.E.T.] (Mehmet Kapanci 
Villa):  
INFORMATION', '1.3  Ethnikis Amynis 
Street.
It leads from the White 
Tower to Syntrivaniou Square 
(see p. 37) and to Agiou 
Dimitriou Street (see p. 39). 
It was laid out after the 1889 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls (a section of its 
Byzantine ramparts still stands 
on Filikis Etaireias Street which 
runs parallel to Ethnikis Amynis 
Street. Until 1912 it was called 
Hamidiye Boulevard, in honour 
of the Sultan Abdul Hamid 
II, as all the buildings along 
the street were his property. 
Today, this is the location of 
the Theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (1962, 
V. Kassandras) housing the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G.) as well as  
the Gallery of the S.M.S. (see p. 
77), and the adjacent Building 
A’ of the S.M.S. (1951, A. 
Nikolopoulos), the Hellenic 
Army Club (1953, P. Mylonas) 
and Alexandros cinema. The 
small Tsirogiannis Park is 
situated nearby and around 
it you will find some popular 
cafés and bars. 
1.4  Diagonios.
This typical downtown 
22', '7
«…There is a homeland for everyone,  
while there is Thessaloniki»
Nikiforos Choumnos, 
14thc. Byzantine dignitary and a scholar.
Nowadays, the historic capital -by right- of Macedonia, 
the land of Alexander the Great, has evolved into a modern 
and particularly charming metropolis. A multitide of 
monuments and cultural assets and the town’s traditional 
ways exist in harmony with the modern aspects and the 
high standard infrastructure, the carefree mood, the spirit 
of hospitality, the vitality of the locals – particularly the 
young – setting the pace of town life, the diversity of 
artistic events, the long list of choices for entertainment, 
the exceptional culinary tradition, and the fresh feel in 
the atmosphere, coming from the seafront, as well as the 
coolness of the northwest wind called Vardaris.   
Thessaloniki’s location is at the centre of a greater area 
with incomparable historical monuments and natural assets 
as it offers the opportunity for a visit to archaeological 
sites known the world over (Ancient Pella, Vergina, Dion, 
Petralona Cave), to areas of exquisite nature (river deltas, 
lakes, Mt Olympus), to the monastic state of Agion Oros 
[the Holy Mountain] as well as to Halkidiki, a famous tourist 
destination. And there is always an opportunity to practice 
sports (swimming, skiing, playing golf etc) or to indulge in 
wellness tourism (hot springs, spas)!
In short, Thessaloniki is a city that can cater for even the 
most demanding needs, any time of the year.']
reference_contexts: ['The International Book Fair in Thessaloniki is an annual event held in the HELEXPO-TIF exhibition center, attracting professionals and book lovers. It features presentations from Greek and foreign publishers, discussions with writers, and various themed corners for children and teenagers. The Society for Macedonian Studies is a key cultural institution in Thessaloniki, focusing on the preservation and promotion of Macedonian history and culture. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall offers a range of performances, while the National Theatre of Northern Greece is the largest cultural organization in northern Greece, hosting various theatrical productions. The city boasts numerous indoor and outdoor theatre stages, providing diverse entertainment options throughout the year.', 'The area along NEA PARALIA features 12 Theme Gardens covering 76,657 m2, ideal for leisure activities. Notable gardens include the Garden of Alexander, Garden of the Seasons with an amphitheater, and the Garden of Music for events. A 3 km cycle path runs through the area, which also houses the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall, inaugurated in 2000, is a prominent venue inspired by Byzantine architecture, hosting various performances and conferences. Nearby, the Depot Area, named after historic tram depot buildings, retains traces of its older atmosphere. The Allatini Mills and the church of Saints Cyril and Methodius are also significant sites in the area.', "Thessaloniki boasts a rich culinary tradition influenced by Byzantine, Ottoman, and various European cuisines, shaped by its multicultural history. The city's gastronomy features traditional tavernas and restaurants that creatively blend local dishes with gourmet elements. Notable delicacies include gyro, souvlaki, and a variety of soups and pies, alongside seafood specialties like mussel pilaf. Desserts play a significant role, with popular items such as bougatsa and trigona Panoramatos. Koulouri Thessalonikis, a sesame-covered bread, is a common snack sold by street vendors. In winter, locals enjoy salep, a unique hot beverage.", 'The text describes two museums: Noesis and Gerovassiliou Wine Museum. Noesis focuses on interactive learning with exhibits like a car exhibition, a planetarium, a cosmotheatre, and a virtual reality simulator. It also offers educational programs on renewable energy and science. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, established in 2008, showcases the history of wine-making and features collections that depict the journey of wine, food pairings, and wine-making equipment. Both museums emphasize visitor engagement and education.', "Eleftherias Square, near the harbor, served as a parking lot and a site of historical significance where 50,000 Jewish residents were gathered by German forces in 1943. A Holocaust Memorial was established in 1997 to commemorate this event. The square is surrounded by notable buildings, including the National Bank of Greece and Alpha Bank, showcasing late neoclassicism and eclectic styles. Kalapothaki Street, starting from the Ladadika area, features pedestrianized sections with neoclassical and Bauhaus-style buildings, popular cafés, and the historic Stein Building. The port area is one of the largest in the southeastern Mediterranean, with a rich history dating back to Constantine the Great's time.", "Thessaloniki's Old Town, untouched by the 1917 fire, features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architecture. It was largely uninhabited until the mid-15th century when the Ottomans settled there due to its favorable climate and strategic location. The area retains its original town planning with narrow alleys and squares, attracting artists and students in recent years. After 1922, many refugees moved in, contributing to the area's diverse cultural heritage.", 'Ano Poli, an area of 3,000 hectares, features a small remnant of an old oak forest and has undergone reforestation since the 1930s. It remains a popular destination for hiking, mountain biking, and picnicking despite urban expansion and a significant fire in 1997. Key attractions include the Zoo, which houses various Greek wildlife species, the Forest Theatre for summer concerts, and the Theatre of the Earth, a notable cultural venue. Visitors can access these sites via bus no. 24 from Eleftherias square. The nearby Sykees area retains its charm with Interwar Period houses amidst modern development.', "The Museum of Greek Children’s Art showcases the creativity of children, depicting Greek history, tradition, and culture through their artwork. It is one of the few museums worldwide dedicated to children's art.", 'Thessaloniki has historically been a key stopover for East-West trade. Today, its town center is a prime shopping destination featuring traditional marketplaces and modern commercial areas. Visitors can find a variety of goods, including food, clothing, and antiques, at reasonable prices. Notable shopping spots include Bit-Pazar for second-hand items and the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall, which offers over 200 shops and entertainment options. Other shopping areas cater to lower budgets, such as Venizelou St. and Egnatia St. The city also boasts stylish boutiques and department stores, particularly around Aristotelous Street and Tsimiski Street.', 'The text describes various historical sites in a town, including Main Street, which was lined with shops and public buildings. The Great Thermae was a large public bath complex featuring marble floors and areas for worship and entertainment. The Houses of Zosa and Lida were decorated with mosaics and sculptures. The Roman Forum, dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century, included luxury houses and a temple for emperor worship. A polygonal building served as a roofed marketplace, while remnants of Early Christian Walls were found nearby. An episcopal basilica was rebuilt in the 5th century after its destruction in the 4th century. The Praetorium functioned as an inn for officials and travelers, with access to the Main Street Thermae. Additionally, the text mentions a climbing route in Olympus National Park and the Petralona Museum, showcasing prehistoric human activity.', 'The text describes day excursions from Thessaloniki, highlighting the monastic state of Mount Athos, which features 20 inhabited monasteries and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. It provides directions to Petralona Cave, located 53 km southeast of Thessaloniki, accessible by coach and taxi or by car. Additionally, it mentions the Lakes Area northeast of Thessaloniki, a National Park with diverse ecosystems ideal for outdoor activities. The area is managed by an agency that offers tours, and visitors are encouraged to try local fish dishes. Lastly, it notes the town of Lagadas, known for its fire-walking custom and modern spa facilities with historical Byzantine bathtubs.', "Lake Koroneia, also known as Lake Agios Vasileios, has seen a reduction in size and depth due to climate conditions and water resource exploitation. Nea Apollonia, a historic village near Lake Volvi, features mineral springs with therapeutic properties and modern health facilities. Lake Volvi is Greece's second-largest natural lake and a Ramsar site, offering birdwatching and various water sports. The area around Volvi includes tourist attractions and communities like Megali Volvi and Mikri Volvi. Rentina, crossed by the Richios River, is noted for its natural beauty and historical ruins.", 'The text describes various historical sites, including the Sanctuary of Isis, which is half-sunk in water and dedicated to the Egyptian goddess. It also mentions the Sanctuary of Olympian Zeus, completed in the Hellenistic period, featuring a large altar and Roman theatre. The Hellenistic Theatre, built in the 3rd century BC, hosts modern events today. The Sanctuary of Asklipios, active until the 3rd century AD, is noted for a statue of the goddess Hygeia. Additionally, the Cemetery Basilica from the 5th century is described, along with fortified walls originally constructed by Cassander, which have been reconstructed over time.', "The Historic Centre features a blend of modern and traditional Macedonian architecture, including the Acheiropoiitos church, a timber-roofed basilica built in 1818. The Nedelkou Building, constructed in 1909, showcases a mix of architectural styles and now serves as the Mount Athos Centre. The Galerius Arch, a significant landmark from 295-305 AD, commemorates Galerius' victory over the Persians and is a popular meeting spot. Nearby, the Rotunda and Panagia Dexia church, which houses a rare icon, add to the area's historical significance. Plateia Syntrivaniou, named after its marble fountain, completes the cultural landscape.", 'The text describes notable landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the OTE Tower, built in 1969, which serves as a telecommunications hub and features a rotating café with stunning views. It also mentions the Alexandreio Melathron, a historic sports arena constructed in 1966, which has hosted significant events and is now home to the Aris basketball team. Additionally, Angelaki Street is highlighted for its cafés and bars popular among university students, as well as its proximity to several radio stations. The 3rd Army Corps area is outlined, featuring the main headquarters building designed by Italian architect V. Poselli in the early 1900s.', "Thessaloniki hosts several cultural institutions, including museums and galleries showcasing Greek art. The collection features works by prominent Greek artists, Byzantine icons spanning five centuries, and Greek engravings. The Gallery of the Society for Macedonian Studies is the city's first visual arts museum, displaying 300 pieces from major 20th-century art movements. The Cultural Centre of Thessaloniki organizes exhibitions in collaboration with local agencies, featuring around 250 pieces of various art forms. The Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, established in 1997, highlights the history of Greek cinema through exhibits categorized into six timelines.", "The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki displays significant art and artifacts from Macedonia, spanning from prehistoric times to late antiquity. The exhibits are categorized into six sections, including the origins of towns, the evolution of Macedonia from the 7th century BC to late antiquity, and the historical significance of Thessaloniki. Notable displays include exceptional gold craftsmanship from ancient cemeteries and a reconstruction of an archaic temple. The museum highlights the region's rich cultural heritage and its transition through various historical periods.", "The Yeni Camii, built in 1902 by architect V. Poselli, served as a mosque for converted Jews and later housed the city's Archaeological Museum. It now functions as a municipal exhibition area with a collection of Roman and Early Christian sculptures. The Hatzimisef Villa, located on Vas. Olgas Ave., was the town's first high school, while the Joseph Modiano villa nearby is currently uninhabited. A bust of King George I, assassinated in 1913, stands at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias Triadas St., crafted by K. Dimitriadis. The Ivan Hatzimisef Villa, built in 1897, now hosts cultural events and an organic food market. Additionally, the building at 34-36 Evzonon Street features classical, baroque, and renaissance architectural styles.", 'The area features historical sites, including a World War II gun emplacement, and is home to diverse salt marshes and wetlands that shelter 178 bird species like flamingoes and cormorants. To reach the location, take the 71 or 71A bus from the Railway Station Stop to N. Michaniona, or use bus lines 02 and 02A to A.S. IKEA station and then switch to buses 72, 72A, or 72B. If driving, follow Ethinikis Antistasis, Georgikis Scholis, and Michanionas avenues.', 'The 6th walk in Thessaloniki highlights several must-see landmarks along NEA PARALIA and VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE. Key attractions include the Monument of Alexander the Great, a large equestrian statue near the White Tower, and the statue of politician Konstantinos Karamanlis. The Makedonia Palace Hotel, a luxury accommodation renovated in the 1990s, is also noted for hosting dignitaries. Another highlight is the Umbrellas sculpture by George Zongolopoulos, a popular photographic spot. Lastly, the Agioi Kyrillos and Methodios Church, dedicated to the saints who spread Christianity to the Slavs, features a well-kept garden.', "The Historic Centre features archaeological sites from the late Roman period, including shops from the 1st to 13th century and the underground Museum of the Roman Forum. A restored Odeon from the 2nd-4th century AD is now used for cultural events. Excavations revealed a round bathhouse from the 1st century BC, along with various artifacts like mosaics, sculptures, and coins. The forum is notable for the 'Enchanted Ones,' a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with Corinthian columns, some of which were moved to the Louvre in 1864. Bit-Pazar, a vibrant market area with antique shops and restaurants, was built in the 1930s and has become popular among students. Nearby, the Jewish Monastirioton Synagogue is the only one that survived World War II. The Experimental School, designed by architect D. Pikionis, was constructed from 1936 to 1938.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki features notable buildings such as the YMCA Building, which showcases a blend of neo-colonial and Byzantine architecture and includes a cultural centre. The Archaeological Museum, designed by P. Karantinos and inaugurated in 1962, is a prime example of modernist architecture in Greece, having undergone renovations to meet contemporary needs. The Museum of Byzantine Culture, built between 1989 and 1993, combines modernism with Greek architectural tradition and is recognized as a historic monument. It includes facilities for exhibitions and events, alongside a café-restaurant and a small amphitheatre.', 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, gastronomy, and lively waterfront.', "Thessaloniki is renowned for its vibrant nightlife, often considered Greece's entertainment capital. The city offers a variety of options, including avant-garde bars, tavernas, ouzo restaurants, and clubs featuring live Greek music, particularly rebetiko. Popular nightlife areas include Ladadika, Kalapothaki Street, and the beachfront cafés. Students frequent Navarinou square, Rotonda, and Angelaki Street, while Ano Poli offers alternative spots for locals. Recently, Valaoritou Street has emerged as a nightlife hotspot, bustling with activity during summer evenings. The Slaughterhouse area features large venues for live Greek music and the city's biggest clubs.", 'The Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association is located in Piraeus, while the Thessaloniki Marina is in Aretsou Kalamaria. Various beaches are accessible, including Aretsou beach and those in Halkidiki, which are popular for swimming. Mineral springs and spas in the area include Lagkadas Spa, Nea Apollonia Spa, and Souroti Spring. The urban bus service covers the city, with main termini at key locations and buses running from 5 am to midnight. Tickets can be purchased for single or multiple trips, and must be validated on the first trip. A cultural bus route highlights historical sites, while open-top tourist buses offer guided tours. Makedonia International Airport is 15 km from the city center, with bus services connecting it to major stations.', "The text describes significant Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including the UNESCO-listed Christian monuments that were once a Metropolitan Church and later converted into a mosque. Key features include the 5th-6th century capitals and stunning mosaics, particularly the dome's Ascension of Christ. The Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, built around 1340, showcases typical Byzantine architecture with depictions of Christ's Ascension. The Rotunda, constructed in 306 AD, features a massive dome and was originally a temple before becoming a church and later a mosque, noted for its preserved mosaics. Additionally, the church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos and the baptistery of Agia Sofia are highlighted for their historical significance.", 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, culinary scene, and lively waterfront.', "The text describes the connection between the town's civic center and various key locations, including Kassandrou Street, Aristotelous Square, and the seafront. It highlights the architectural features of buildings along the street, which house various businesses and institutions. The church of Agia Theodora is noted as a significant landmark at the junction of Aristotelous and Ermou Streets. Nikis Avenue, known as Palia Paralia, runs from the harbor to the White Tower and has historical significance, having been opened by the Turks in 1882. Today, it is a popular area filled with cafés, bars, and pedestrian activity. The avenue features several notable landmarks, including interwar period mansions and the Thessaloniki Club. The text emphasizes the vibrant atmosphere of Nikis Avenue, frequented by locals and tourists alike.", 'The text describes various locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki, including the historical significance of the eastern walls and the neoclassical G. Gennimatas hospital. It mentions Agios Nikolaos Orphanos and Kallitheas Square, highlighting the picturesque area and its major streets. Additionally, it notes the former location of the Children’s Museum of Thessaloniki and introduces Seich Sou, the largest forested area near the city.', 'The historic center of Thessaloniki features a shopping mall that was reshaped between 1995-1997, retaining its original exterior while now housing shops, cinemas, cafés, and restaurants around a central atrium. Notable buildings from the early 20th century are located at the junction of Tsimiski and Karolou Dil Streets, currently serving as shops and offices. The traditional market area, west of Aristotelous Street and south of Egnatia Street, is filled with small shops, malls, and arcades dating back to the Turkish Occupation, offering a variety of products including food, spices, and fabrics. Modiano Market, built in 1922, is a glass-roofed structure with 140 food shops and popular restaurants. The Vlali-Kapani and Athonos-Vatikioti Markets, designed by Ernest Hébrard, feature two-storeyed malls with archways and are connected to Aristotelous Street.', 'The Greek National Tourism Organisation promotes tourism in Greece through its website, www.visitgreece.gr.', 'The Palace of Galerius is an open-air archaeological museum in the historic center, constructed in the late 3rd to early 4th century. It is part of the Galerian Complex, which included significant structures like the Hippodrome and Rotunda. The palace served as a residence for emperors until its destruction in the 7th century and is a major monument of Late Antiquity. Key features include the Octagon, an audience hall with elaborate decoration; a colonnaded yard; a two-storeyed tank for water collection; a monumental Basilica used for official gatherings; and a bathhouse with various bathing facilities.', 'Chortiatis is a small suburb located on Mt. Chortiatis, known for its hiking trails and historical significance, including remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct. Thermi, situated 15 km southeast of Thessaloniki, retains a countryside feel and was historically significant as the harbor of ancient Thermi, famous for its hot springs. The central square of Thermi, Paramana Square, is noted for its futuristic design and serves as a hub for local businesses. An artificial lake nearby offers recreational opportunities and hosts the Dam Music Festival in summer, while the Environmental Park provides various sports facilities.', 'Thessaloniki offers various sports facilities, including an 18-hole golf course at Porto Carras Grand Resort and proximity to several ski centers. Notable ski centers include Seli, Elatochori, 3-5 Pigadia, Lailias, Vora, and Falakro, each with different elevations, runs, and amenities. Information for each ski center, including contact details and websites, is provided. Additionally, resources for local tourism, archaeological sites, and weather forecasts are available online.', 'Noesis is a unique science center and technology museum in Greece, completed in 2004, featuring exhibitions, a digital library, and an amphitheater. It can be accessed via public transport or car from Thessaloniki. The seaside areas of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada, located 20 km from the city center, were settled by refugees in 1923 and have since developed into popular suburbs and resorts. These areas boast Blue Flag beaches, water sports facilities, and a vibrant seafront with tavernas and bars.', 'The text describes various day excursions near Ancient Pella, including Aravissou springs, Platanopotamos Lake, and Dytiko plane-tree forest. It provides directions to Ancient Pella from Thessaloniki and mentions the military Museum of Balkan Wars. Additionally, it highlights the historical significance of Vergina (Aiges), the former capital of Macedon, detailing its importance from the 10th-8th century BC until its destruction by the Romans in 168 BC. The archaeological site is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, featuring the Royal Tombs discovered by archaeologist Manolis Andronikos in 1977.', "The 6th walk along NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE showcases a busy street with impressive late 19th to early 20th-century buildings. Notable sites include Allatini Villa, built in 1898, which served various purposes over the years, including housing the University of Thessaloniki and a military hospital. Casa Bianca, constructed in 1912, features eclectic and art nouveau elements and now hosts a branch of the Municipal Art Gallery. The Nehama Villa, built in 1907, is another significant structure on the avenue. Mordoch Villa, established in 1905, has a rich history, including use as military barracks and a polyclinic, and currently houses the Municipal Art Gallery. These villas reflect the area's historical character amidst urbanization.", "The historic centre features the White Tower, originally known as the Tower of the Janissaries, which served as a jail and now hosts exhibitions on Thessaloniki's history. Visitors can enjoy panoramic views from the top and relax in the surrounding square, which is a hotspot for boat bars. The Royal Theatre, built in 1940 and renovated in 1996, has a capacity of 800 and is part of the State Theatre of Northern Greece. Ethnikis Amynis Street connects the White Tower to Syntrivaniou Square and was established after the demolition of city walls in 1889. Previously named Hamidiye Boulevard, it is now home to various cultural institutions, including the Theatre of the Society for Macedonian Studies and popular cafés and bars nearby.", 'The Agora, a 4th century BC building complex, served as the administrative and cultural hub of the town, featuring a large court and various commercial shops. Excavations have revealed several temples, including those dedicated to the Mother of Gods and Aphrodite. The Palace, located on a northern hill, dates back to the 4th century BC and includes a peristyle and royal quarters. The Eastern cemetery contains rock-hewn cist graves from the Copper Age to Classical times. The Alexander the Great Bathhouse is a notable Hellenistic bathing facility. The Archaeological Museum in Northern Greece showcases five thematic categories, including daily life, public life, religious practices, cemetery finds, and the architectural design of the palace, along with information about Alexander the Great.', 'The text describes various historical buildings along Vas. Olgas Avenue in Thessaloniki, including the Folklife and Ethnological Museum of Macedonia – Thrace, which was once a residence of banker Jacob Modiano. Other notable buildings include a former private residence that now serves as a nursery school, the Melissa Building which housed an orphanage and now hosts the Centre for Byzantine Research, and the School for the Blind, originally built as a private residence. The Jeborga Villa, once the Italian Consulate, is now deserted. The Yeni Mosque and Modiano Villa are also mentioned for their eclectic architectural features.', "The text describes several historical churches in a region, highlighting their architectural features and historical significance. The UNESCO Byzantine Monuments are noted for their symmetrical proportions and Palaeologan art, which was covered when converted into a mosque. The Panagia Chalkeon Church, built in 1128, represents the architecture of the 'School of Constantinople' and was also converted into a mosque. Acheiropoitos Church, founded in the 5th century, features a three-aisled basilica and was the first church turned into a mosque after the Turkish conquest. Agia Sofia Church, built in the mid-7th century, is a significant early Christian structure modeled after the Hagia Sophia in Constantinople.", 'The text describes several historical sites in the historic center, including Yeni Hamam, built in 1531, which served as a bathing place until 1944-45. Alaca Imaret, constructed in 1484, features skilled masonry and is occasionally used for cultural events. The Profitis Ilias Church and Panagia Lagoudiani Church, a 14th-century Byzantine basilica, are also highlighted, with the latter named after a hare that led to the discovery of an icon. The Ataturk Museum, located in the former residence of Kemal Ataturk, showcases his life and includes a café. Additionally, Kaftanzogleio Stadium is noted as the largest stadium in the city, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art is mentioned.', 'Thessaloniki offers various transportation options including a passenger railway station, intercity bus services, and taxi services. The railway station provides information on domestic and international timetables. The Macedonia Intercity Bus Station connects to regional areas and islands. Taxis operate with taximeters, and fare rates vary by time of day. Numerous museums and archaeological sites are available for visitors, including the Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki and the Museum of Byzantine Culture. Additional cultural sites include the Jewish Museum and the War Museum. For more information on museums, visitors can check the provided websites.', 'The text describes various notable locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki. Tsitsani Square features a bust of composer V. Tsitsanis and is surrounded by well-tended houses. Eptapyrgiou Street runs along the northern city walls, showcasing traditional buildings and the old Zihne Camii mosque. Moni Vlatadon is mentioned as a point of interest. Portara is one of the main gates of the northern city walls, adorned with ceramics and inscriptions. The Acropolis, specifically Eptapyrgio (Yedi Kule), is highlighted as a significant fortified area within the city walls. The area is popular among both residents and tourists.', 'Epanomi is a picturesque town 25 km SE of Thessaloniki, known for its beautiful beaches and a wetland refuge for over 80 bird species. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, unique in northern Greece, is located nearby. Nea Michaniona, a major fishing center 32 km S of Thessaloniki, features the largest fleet of deep-sea fish boats in Greece and a vibrant seafront with café-bars and tavernas. Popular beaches like Tourbani and Angelochori have received Blue Flag awards for quality. Angelochori, a small village near Nea Michaniona, offers views of the Olympus massif and remnants of an Ottoman stronghold. The area provides modern water sports facilities from Peraia to Epanomi.', "The Lazare church in Paris, once a hospital and refugee center, was declared a historic monument in 1980 and renovated in 1997 for cultural events in Thessaloniki. It now serves as a multi-purpose venue, housing the National Theatre of Northern Greece, a café-restaurant, and hosting outdoor performances. The area also features five old tobacco warehouses, remnants of the city's tobacco trade, with one converted into a luxury hotel and others housing educational and commercial spaces. Additionally, the Stavroupoli Botanical Garden spans 0.5 hectares, showcasing over 1000 plant species and offering recreational facilities. The Serbian monument is located in the Zeitenlik allied military cemetery.", 'The text describes various attractions in Thessaloniki, including the historic center, shopping streets, and museums. It highlights the eclectic-style building housing the local Greek Scouts and the upscale shopping area with expensive boutiques and art galleries. The Museum for the Macedonian Struggle, a neo-classical building, is noted for its historical significance and previous functions. Nearby, the metropolitan church of Agios Gregorios Palamas features Byzantine and neo-classical architecture, along with the Ecclesiastical Museum showcasing a significant collection.', "Vergina, located 63 km SW of Thessaloniki, features a traditional Jewish quarter with Roman, Ottoman, and Industrial age monuments. Visitors can explore the Public Central Library and relax in parks. Dion, an archaeological site under Olympus, was sacred to ancient Macedonians and hosted the 'Olympia Games in Dion.' The area is rich in biodiversity and includes significant sites like the Vafyras sacred springs, the temple of Demeter, and the Sanctuary of Zeus Hypsistos. Dion flourished until the 5th century AD before being abandoned due to seismic activity.", "Thessaloniki is a child-friendly city with numerous activities, including bicycle rides along waterfront bike lanes and visits to theme parks. The region is also known for its rich wine-making tradition, featuring a variety of grapes like Roditis, Asyrtiko, and Cabernet Sauvignon. The Wine Producers Association offers excursions through the 'Wine Roads of North Greece,' combining visits to wineries with historical sites. Families can enjoy various fun activities and games throughout the city.", "The text describes various cultural and historical sites in Thessaloniki, including a small museum dedicated to the founder of modern Turkey, the Teloglion Foundation of Art with its modern facilities, and the Kaftanzogleio Stadium, which was the largest in Greece until 1982 and is home to the city's oldest football team, Iraklis. The stadium also hosted events during the 2004 Athens Olympic Games and is near the Olympic Museum.", "The text describes various museums in Thessaloniki, including the archaeological museum that showcases excavated sites and the process of maintaining an archaeological museum. It highlights temporary exhibitions related to Byzantine heritage. The White Tower Exhibition presents Thessaloniki's history through multimedia and is organized into seven thematic categories across different floors. Additionally, the Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki, established by the local Jewish community, promotes Sephardic heritage and features a research center, library, and audiovisual center. Its permanent exhibitions cover topics such as the Jewish necropolis and the history of the Jewish community up to World War II.", "This publication by the Greek National Tourism Organisation, supervised by Angela Varela and coordinated by Eleni Mitraki, features contributions from various professionals including journalist Yannis Ragos and translator Angeliki Christopoulou. It includes photo credits from multiple photographers and is designed by Zoe Tzomentzidou. The publication is not for sale and is available through the Greek National Tourism Organisation's website.", "Thessaloniki offers various outdoor activities such as hiking and mountain biking in the suburban forests of Seich Sou and Chortiatis, as well as relaxing by the Deltas of Gallikos and Axios-Loudias-Aliakmonas rivers. Educational programs for children are available in most museums, particularly at the unique Children's Museum. The Noesis Science Centre and Technology Museum provides fun and educational experiences related to science and technology. Pikrolimni is accessible by car or a daily bus from Thessaloniki.', "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in a city, focusing on Agia Sofia Square, which features greenery and significant buildings like the Longos and Chatzidimitriou Buildings. It highlights the square's pedestrian-friendly areas and a monument commemorating the Genocide of Pontic Greeks. Navarinou Square is noted for its vibrant atmosphere, popular among students, with numerous cafés, bars, and shops. The square also has a fountain and a playground, and visitors are encouraged to explore nearby streets and the church of Nea Panagia, dating back to 1727.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki, particularly the Ladadika area, has transformed from a downgraded region post-WWII to a vibrant hotspot with restaurants, clubs, and live music venues since the 1990s. Key attractions include Morichovou square and Petrakaki square, featuring the Ottoman Post Office Mansion. Tsimiski Street, a major commercial hub, connects YMCA square to Ladadika and is known for its shops, offices, and cafés. Notable buildings include the Kazes Building, designed by Xenophon Paionidis in 1924, and Agios Minas Church, which has historical significance dating back to early Christianity.', 'The text describes significant historical sites in ancient Macedonia, including a palace with a peristyle, a monumental gateway, and a temple dedicated to Hercules. It mentions an ancient theatre built around 340 BC, where King Philip II was assassinated. Additionally, it details religious sites near the theatre, including temples dedicated to goddess Euclea and Kyveli, along with remnants of royal votive offerings. The Acropolis features five towers and thick fortification walls, with house foundations dating from the 5th to 1st century BC. The town of Veroia, located near Vergina, was historically important for Macedonians and visited by Apostle Paul, earning the nickname Little Jerusalem due to its many surviving Byzantine churches and a longstanding Jewish presence.', "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Hippodrome, which was a center of social activity until 390 AD when a massacre led to its closure. It highlights the Thessaloniki History Centre and the 18th-century Agios Antonios church nearby. The Arched Hall, located at the intersection of Gounari and Svolou streets, was used for symposia and had access to the imperial box in the Hippodrome. Additionally, remnants of a theatre-stadium on Apellou Street are noted, linked to the martyrdom of Agios Dimitrios. The text also mentions three churches on Egnatia Street, particularly the Panagouda Church, built in 1818 on the site of an older church destroyed by fire. The area is rich in history, reflecting the city's cultural heritage.", "Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to Roman times, connecting Dyrrhachium and Constantinople. It serves as a busy shopping area with notable eclectic and art deco buildings from the early 20th century. Key attractions include Kolomvou Square, a lively hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is currently undergoing renovations. The mosque will soon host an exhibition of archaeological finds from metro excavations. Egnatia Street splits the city's historic center, making it a significant thoroughfare for both locals and tourists.", 'The text describes the historical and cultural significance of suburbs and outskirts of Thessaloniki, including ancient tombs and a Neolithic settlement. It provides directions to Kalochori via bus or car. Kalamaria, a prominent suburb, features green spaces and a shopping center, with a history of Greek refugees settling there in the 1920s. Key sites include Sofouli Street, the Little Palace (formerly a royal residence), and the Kodra former military camp, which is being transformed into a park. Excavations at Kodra revealed a settlement from the archaic and classical periods, possibly linked to Ancient Thermi.', "The text describes various historical and architectural landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the West of the Centre-Stavroupoli inaugurated in 1962, which connects the city to Greece and the Balkans. The Old Railway Station, built in 1894, is now a cargo station and was historically significant during the German occupation. The Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), constructed by the Ottomans in 1546, served as a city stronghold and features well-preserved sections of the old city walls. The De La Salle Complex, built in 1926, now houses the city's Administrative Courts and showcases neobyzantine architecture. Lastly, the Vienni Hotel, established in 1925, reflects eclectic architectural trends and currently accommodates private company offices."]

The city's gastronomy is a unique blend of Byzantine, Christian, Ottoman, and European influences, and features a wide range of delicious and authentic dishes, such as gyro, souvlaki, patsa, and moussaka. The traditional tavernas, ouzo restaurants, and luxury restaurants all contribute to the city's vibrant culinary scene.

In contrast, the cultural and historical sites are often associated with formal events, educational programs, and artistic performances. However, the culinary traditions and local delicacies are more about the everyday experience and the enjoyment of good food and company. Both aspects are deeply intertwined and reflect the city's unique character and identity.

Thessaloniki's cultural and historical significance is not just limited to the city's landmarks, but also to its people and their traditions. The city's history and culture are deeply rooted in its Mediterranean and Balkan heritage, and are reflected in its cuisine, architecture, and way of life.

In summary, Thessaloniki's cultural and historical significances are an integral part of the city
reference: The cultural and historical significances of various sites in Thessaloniki, such as the International Book Fair, Society for Macedonian Studies, and National Theatre of Northern Greece, highlight the city's rich heritage and artistic contributions, while its culinary traditions and local delicacies reflect a blend of influences from Byzantine, Ottoman, and European cuisines, showcasing the city's multicultural history.

3.1  Mt. Olympus.
The highest Greek mountain 
(2,918 m.) is globally known  
as the residence of the 12 gods 
of ancient Greek mythology. 
It is the first National Park of 
Greece (1938); in 1981 it was 
designated a World Biosphere 
Reserve area by UNESCO. It 
includes 4,500 hectares of 
oak, black pine, beech, Bosnian 
pine, alpine vegetation, and 
1,700 species of flora; recorded 
fauna includes 32 species of 
mammals, 108 species of 
birds, a great variety of reptile 
and insect species, and an 
abundance of butterflies. The 
mountain is very popular with 
hiking and mountaineering fans, 
there are six refuges and nine 
mountain routes (which include 
part of the E4 European path) 
all the way to the highest peaks 
namely Mytikas and Stefani.
3.2  Ancient Pydna.
It lies 43 km N of Dion and 
it was built in the 8th – 7th c. 
BC. During the 4th c. BC the 
Macedon king Philip II made 
Pydna the administrative 
centre of the district. In 168 
BC, Roman troops defeated 
the Macedonian army near 
the town, and that meant 
the beginning of Roman rule 
in Macedonia. Gradually the 
town went into decline and 
was successively occupied by 
Bulgarians, western Europeans 
and Turks, and got eventually 
deserted in the 15th c. 
Excavations have unearthed

SPORTS 
Thessaloniki has a long 
tradition in sports. In recent 
decades, major sports events 
have taken place in the city 
(finals of european football and 
basketball games, international 
track and  field events, a

response:
Two factors contribute to the growth and development of suburbs like Kalochori and Sindos in relation to their proximity to industrial areas:
1. **Industrial Park**: The proximity of Kalochori and Sindos to the Thessaloniki Industrial Park is a significant factor in their growth and development. The industrial park has attracted various industries, leading to job creation and economic growth in the surrounding areas.
2. **Accessibility**: The proximity of these suburbs to major city roads and the waterfront, as well as the availability of transportation options (e.g., bus lines), makes them easily accessible to the city center and other industrial areas. This accessibility has facilitated the growth of industries, services, and residential areas in these suburbs.
reference: The growth and development of suburbs like Kalochori and Sindos are influenced by their proximity to industrial areas, with Kalochori being a rapidly rising residential suburb near the city and Sindos experiencing considerable growth due to the Thessaloniki Industrial Park.
