7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque.', '16
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
14	\x07AGIOS NIKOLAOS 
[SAINT NICHOLAS] 
ORPHANOS CHURCH
It was built in the 1310s,  
as a dependency of Vlatadon 
Monastery and it served as a 
monastery main church. Within 
the same grounds there used 
to be an orphanage at earlier 
times – hence the name 
“Orphanos” [meaning Orphan]. 
It is an aisleless timber-roofed 
church sided by an ambulatory 
forming the shape “Π”.  
The 14th c. murals inside are 
true masterpieces depicting 
scenes of Dodekaorto [the 
Twelve major religious feasts  
of the year], of the Passion  
of Christ, the Resurrection and 
the Liturgical Cycle as well as 
figures of saints; the monument 
is considered as one of the 
best preserved in Thessaloniki. 
It is surrounded by lush and 
serene gardens.
15	CITY WALLS
Thessaloniki was walled 
immediately after it was 
founded by Cassander; in 
390 AD a series of large-
scale changes took place by 
Theodosius I. In the Byzantine 
times a harbour was constructed

AGIA AIKATERINI

This 14th c. Byzantine church is 
situated in the centre of Agia 
Aikaterini town quarter in Ano

Monastery] or Moni Akapniou 
[Akapniou Monastery]. It was 
situated in the area of the 
Byzantine palaces and this 
is why the Turks had named 
the area Balat (Palace) and 
the church Eski Saray Camii 
(Old Palace mosque). It is a 
tetrastyle cross-in-square 
domed church with features 
related to the monasterial 
architecture of Mount Athos. 
The central dome is supported 
by granite columns in the 
shape of a cross, the building’s 
central part was enlarged by 
the addition of two conchs 
[semi-domes] whereas in 
the west section there is a 
rectangular cupolaed narthex. 
The murals (14th c.) depict 
images of saints and scenes 
from the life and miracles of 
Christ. Also, at the junction of 
Olympiados and Amfilochias 
Sts. there is a surviving 
ottoman fountain.
11	\x07BYZANTINE BATHS  
(KULE KAFE)
It is located on Romfei Sq. (see 
p. 43) in Ano Poli and it is the 
only surviving Byzantine bath 
house, a domed 13th c. building 
made of brick, which was 
open to the public until 1940. 
7. 
Profitis Ilias 
Church.
8. 
Moni Vlatadon 
is right in the 
heart of Upper 
(Old) City.

reference_contexts:
['1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
other name; there are also 
many cafés and bars. In the 
adjoining Melenikou st. you will 
see segments of the town’s 
eastern walls.
7 	\x07AGIOS PANTELEIMONAS 
CHURCH
It is on Iasonidou st., pretty 
close to Rotunda. According 
to certain scholars, this 
was the main church of 
the Monastery of Kyr Isaac 
or Theotokos Perivleptos, 
founded by Jacob, the 
Metropolitan Bishop of 
Thessaloniki (1295-1314). 
It is a tetrastyle cross-in-
square domed church with a 
surrounding portico ending 
to the east in two chapels. 
During the Turkish Occupation 
it was changed into a mosque 
under the name Ishakiye 
Camii (the mosque of Isaac). 
Remaining murals date to 
the 13th – 14th c. and depict 
saints and prelates as well  
the Virgin Mary.
8 	\x07
AGIOS DIMITRIOS 
CHURCH
It is the best known Byzantine 
church of the town as Agios 
Dimitrios [St. Demetrius] is 
Thessaloniki’s patron saint. It 
was built during the 7th c. on 
the ruins of a 5th c. Basilica and 
in 1493 it was converted into 
a mosque. It was destroyed 
in 1917 by the fire but it was 
restored and reopened in 
1948. It is a five-aisle transept 
basilica with a women’s gallery 
and a narthex. The sculpted 
decorative motifs originate 
from the 5th c. basilica and 
other buildings and this 
explains their variety; equally 
interesting are the capitals (5th 
and 6th c.). The mosaics found 
on the west side date to the 
5th c. while those on the piers 
around the sanctuary [bema] 
are later additions. Those 
depicting the saint among 
children, flanked by the bishop 
and the prefect are of great 
value. In the basement lies the 
Krypt on the site where Roman 
public baths used to be. This 
is the place of martyrdom for 
Saint Demetrius in 303 or 305. 
When the 5th c. Church was 
built, the baths became a place 
of special worship and the water 
flowing was believed to be holy. 
Since 1988 it is an exhibition 
area for sculptures, capitals, 
panels, vessels etc, where 
cultural events also take place.
6
']

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous 
monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in 
a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s 
historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature.

response: Thessaloniki has a centuries-old multicultural history associated with great empires, including the Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Rule. The city has kept its urban character and has remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. The numerous monuments, dating to many historical periods, coexist in a singular and charming way and manifest Thessaloniki’s historical multicultural and cosmopolitan nature. The city's centuries-old multicultural history has been associated with great empires, as it has known the Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups (Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The city's architectural heritage is a testament to its rich history, with many monuments and buildings that date back to various historical periods. The historic centre of Thessaloniki is a hub of cultural significance, with many exhibits and architectural features that reflect the city's multicultural history. The city's past is evident in its many historic buildings and monuments, which have been preserved and protected for future generations to appreciate. ['3.1  Dioikitirio.
It was built in 1891 by 
architect V. Poselli to be used 
as the ottoman Administration 
House [Konaki] of the city. 
The style is neoclassical 
with renaissance features 
and originally it was a three-
storey building (the fourth 
floor was added in 1955). 
Today it houses the Ministry 
of Macedonia-Thrace where 
protest marches usually 
wind up. In 1990, following 
excavations which took place 
in the square in front of 
Dioikitirio, fragments of roman, 
early-christian, byzantine 
and ottoman houses were 
unearthed; this shows that  
the area has always been  
the administrative centre  
of the city.
3.2  Agios Dimitrios [Saint 
Demetrius]
(see p. 11)
39']
response: The Dioikitirio was built in 1891 by architect V. Poselli to be used as the Ottoman Administration House [Konaki] of the city. It was later converted into the Ministry of Macedonia-Thrace and is now used as the protest march endpoint. The building is considered a significant historical landmark in Thessaloniki, Greece, and its design reflects neoclassical and baroque elements. The area around Dioikitirio has been the administrative centre of the city throughout history, and excavations in the square in front of the building have uncovered fragments of Roman, early-Christian, Byzantine, and Ottoman houses. The building has been listed as a monument since 1984.
reference: The historical significance of the Dioikitirio lies in its role as the Ottoman Administration House, its neoclassical architecture, and its location as the administrative center of the city, evidenced by the discovery of various historical fragments during excavations.

GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy

impressive delicacies

(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed

Ever since the 4th c. BC when it was founded, 
Thessaloniki has kept its urban character and has 
remained a civic centre and the hub of that region. 
The city’s centuries-old multicultural history has been 
associated with great empires, as it has known the 
Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Rule. The town was also 
greatly influenced by many ethnic and religious groups 
(Jews, Latins, Armenians and others) as well as Greeks 
from Constantinople, Pontus [modern-day northeastern 
Turkey] and Asia Minor [a.k.a. Anatolia]. The numerous

a day trip (it’s only a short

led to the finding of the icon 
of Panagia. Odigitria (Virgin 
Mary Guiding All Men) as 
well as Saint Demetrius are 
honoured as patron saints  
of the city.

residence was built in the late

of Kemal Ataturk, born  
in Thessaloniki (1880? - 1938). 
In the yard, you will see  
a pomegranate tree his father  
had planted there. It is a building 
now painted in its original colour 
- pink – and houses

THESSALONIKI CINEMA 
MUSEUM
It was created in 1997  
and the opening coincided 
with the European Capital  
of Culture events which were 
hosted by Thessaloniki that 
year. It is closely related 
to the city history, as the 
Thessaloniki International Film 
Festival has been taking place 
in the city since 1960 (see p. 
108). Exhibits tell the history 
of the Greek cinema and are 
classified in six timelines, 
namely Manakia brothers, 
1900-1940, 1940-1960, 
1960-1970, 1970-1990,  
and 1990 and beyond. Among 
the items on display are rare

reference_contexts:
['GASTRONOMY AND WINES
GASTRONOMY AND WINES
Thessaloniki has a great 
culinary tradition which has 
become an intrinsic part  
of the character and mentality  
of the locals. The city’s multi-
cultural character across the 
ages has added an indelible 
stamp on its traditional cuisine 
which includes Byzantine, 
Christian, Ottoman influences 
and elements contributed by 
the large numbers of Minor 
Asia refugees who flowed in 
the town during the 1920s, 
and also Jewish and western 
European influences, thus 
creating unique culinary 
combinations. Downtown (see 
p. 15-41), in Ano Poli (see p. 
42 - 49) and in the seaside 
suburbs and city outskirts (see 
p. 63 - 69), the traditional 
tavernas, ouzo restaurants and 
luxury restaurants highlight the 
local traditional gastronomy 
often creatively mixing it with 
gourmet tastes. 
Thessaloniki’s gastronomy 
can boast some pretty 
impressive delicacies 
[mezedes] such as gyro [slices 
of meat roasted on a spit] and 
souvlaki, patsa, a variety of 
soup, pies, Anatolian dishes 
(tzigerosarmades, giaprakia, 
gardoumpes, kebab etc), 
lake and sea fish, seafood 
delicacies (mussel pilaf, 
saganaki with shrimps, stuffed 
calamari etc). Confectionery 
is also an important part 
of local gastronomy and it 
features the renowned syrupy 
cakes and pastry originating 
from Istanbul (ekmek kadayifi, 
kazandibi, tulumba etc) the 
well-known bougatsa [filled 
either with cheese or with 
cream], galaktompoureko 
[a type of pastry filled with 
custard], and last but not least 
trigona Panoramatos [a cone-
shaped syrupy cream-filled puff 
pastry] (see p. 65). Koulouri 
Thessalonikis is also worthy 
of mention. It is a sesame-
covered piece of bread and 
an everyday snack for locals, 
which you can find in the 
morning hours sold by street 
vendors or at the baker’s. 
During the winter months, you 
can try salep, an interesting 
hot beverage.
119
120
']
response: Thessaloniki's history has added an indelible stamp on its traditional cuisine, which includes Byzantine, Christian, Ottoman influences and elements contributed by the large numbers of Minor Asia refugees who flowed in the town during the 1920s, and also Jewish and western European influences. This unique culinary combination is a result of the city's multicultural history, with various nationalities coexisting and contributing to its gastronomy.
reference: Thessaloniki's history shapes its cuisine through its multicultural influences, including Byzantine, Christian, Ottoman, and contributions from Minor Asia refugees, resulting in unique culinary combinations and traditional dishes.

the corner of Ermou and Agias 
Sofias streets, and the 1924 
Chatzidimitriou Building (at the 
point where Ermou and Kar. Dil 
Streets meet). The square is 
also the location where Pavlou 
Mela and Iktinou (pedestrian 
zone) Streets begin; along 
with the adjacent Zefxidos 
Street they are a hot spot area 
for buys, or a coffee, a drink or 
a meal.', '10
1st walk: 
UNESCO BYZANTINE MONUMENTS
Thessaloniki has been  
one of the first towns to 
know the Christian religion by 
the Apostle Paul; during the 
Byzantine period it used to be 
the second most important 
city of the empire (co-reigning 
city) after Constantinople. 
At that time (4th – 15th c.), 
Christian monuments and 
churches were constructed in 
the town, and these make up 
a diachronic typology with a 
decisive influence on the entire 
Byzantine world. The following 
early-Christian and Byzantine 
monuments of the town are 
considered to be excellent 
specimens of the Byzantine 
church-building and art, and 
for this reason UNESCO 
declared them to be World 
Heritage Monuments, in 1988. 
A tour across this unique 
open-air Byzantine museum  
is truly a special experience.
1 	\x07HOLY TWELVE  
APOSTLES CHURCH
One of the town’s oldest 
churches was built in 1310 – 
1314 under the sponsorship  
of Patriarch Nephon I. It used 
to be a katholicon [main church] 
of a monastery dedicated to 
Theotokos [Mother of God] as 
shown by the mural depicting 
Theotokos and the Founder, 
as well as by the iconography 
on the aisle with images of 
the Holy Virgin’s life.']

response: Museums in Thessaloniki collaborate with each other to promote cultural activities, organize thematic exhibitions, and participate in educational and research programs. They also collaborate with other cultural institutions to support and promote the cultural heritage of the city. For example, the Archaeological Museum, the Museum of Byzantine Culture, the State Museum of Contemporary Art, the Macedonian Museum of Modern Art, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art collaborate to support cultural activities and promote the cultural heritage of the city. Additionally, the 5 Museums of Thessaloniki website provides more information on these collaborations. Furthermore, museums also promote culture and heritage through exhibitions and events, such as the Archaeological Museum's exhibition of Christian monuments and churches, which is part of the UNESCO World Heritage Monuments of Thessaloniki. Overall, museums play a significant role in promoting culture and heritage in Thessaloniki.
reference: Museums help with culture and heritage by discovering the past through archaeological sites and organizing temporary exhibitions and cultural events related to Byzantine legacy.

Starting from the year it was

the history of Thessaloniki is

Noesis –Science Centre

It is the only one of its kind 
in Greece! Construction of

4 	\x07TERPSITHEA DISTRICT 
(STAVROUPOLI)
This is a relatively quiet area

the city centre; the urban and

and exhibits, see p. 76).

It was built in 1969 to plans

Melathron.
Also known as Palais des 
Sports, this sports arena is 
located on the NE side of the 
Thessaloniki International Fair 
grounds. Constructed in 1966, 
it has played an active part 
in Thessaloniki’s history ever 
since, as major sporting, art 
as well as political events have 
taken place in it over the years.  
It is a round edifice with a 
seating for 4,800, and it used 
to be the largest indoor sports 
arena in Greece until 1985. 
Today, it is the home ground of 
Aris basketball team.

MUSEUM AREA
The area is considered  
as one of the most privileged

of its proximity to the beach;

and cultural institutions.
1 	\x07
THE WHITE TOWER 
AREA

Germanou) and where the old

MUST SEE:
1.1  The White Tower.
This is the city’s most 
famous landmark - 
monument.', '49
5th walk: 
ANO POLI (OLD TOWN)
The quarter was created mainly 
to provide housing for the 
refugees who settled there 
in the early 20th c.; however 
traces of settlements exist 
which date as far back as the 
2nd c. AD. In the lush greenery 
of the Municipal Grove there 
is a Municipal Theatre, where 
major cultural events are held 
during the summer months, 
and an open-air cinema. 
Further south, on a low hill, you 
will see the imposing church 
of Agioi Theodoroi, built on 
ruins of a 7th c. Byzantine 
church, where the view of the 
entire city is amazing. In the 
neighbouring Elpidos Street 
towards the city walls you will 
see a group of refugee houses 
– the area is in the process of 
being changed into a “Cultural 
Neighbourhood”.
How to get there: To 
reach Sykees, you can either 
walk from Ano Poli or take 
the bus no. 23 (terminus at 
Eleftherias sq.) and get off at 
Agios Charalampos stop.

response:
Exhbits in Thessaloniki show city's history changes through the following ways:
1. The White Tower Exhibition: Depicts the history of Thessaloniki from its founding until the present day through an array of multimedia applications, special structures, printed graphic design compositions, and archaeological material.
2. Discovering the Past: Excavated sites in the city and the procedure for creating and maintaining an archaeological museum are described in room 11.
3. Temporary exhibitions and events: The Museum organises temporary exhibitions and cultural events, most of which are associated with Thessaloniki’s and Northern Greece’s Byzantine legacy.
4. Thessaloniki Cinema Museum: Exhibits tell the history of the Greek cinema and are classified in six timelines, such as Manakia brothers, 1900-1940, 1940-1960, 1960-1970, 1970-1990, and 1990 and beyond.
5. Water Museum: The Water Museum is housed in the adjacent old main pumping station of the Water Company (1890-94), which was running until 1978.
6. Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki: The Jewish Museum of Thessaloniki was created following an initiative of the Jewish Community
reference: Exhibits in Thessaloniki showcase the city's history changes through multimedia applications, thematic categories, and displays of Jewish heritage, illustrating the evolution of the city from its founding to the present day.

complex of 14 listed industrial

Two contiguous buildings

one of which is a Children’s

14,500 volumes.

Construction took place possibly 
around 1340 and it is a typical 
example of the transitional type 
in Byzantine church-building, 
found particularly in Macedonia. 
Fine depictions of the Ascension 
of Christ, the Prophets and the 
Divine Liturgy decorate the dome.
6 	ROTUNDA [ROTONTA]
This impressive round building 
lies on the route connecting 
the triumphal arch of Galerius 
(Kamara, see p. 37) and the 
Palace of Galerius (see p. 29). 
It has a diameter of 24.5 m. 
and its gigantic dome is 30 
m. high. It was built in 306 
AD by Galerius, probably as a 
temple of Zeus or Kaveiros or 
as a mausoleum; in the 5th c. 
it was converted into a church 
dedicated to the Holy Bodiless 
Powers. The 5th c. outstanding 
preserved mosaics impress 
with their variety of themes, 
their naturalistic rendering, 
the colour diversity and the 
brilliance of the gold and 
silver tesserae. In 1591 it was 
turned into a mosque when a 
towering minaret was added, 
which survives today. In the 
square, next to Rotunda, lies 
the small church of Agios  
Georgios [St. George] whence 
the monument took its

facilities. During the summer

Another favourite area to 
Thessalonians is Kalamaria 
(see p. 64) and, a bit further

Apart from the 
entertainment options, 
a host of artistic events 
get organised in the city 
throughout the entire

Thessaloniki Concert Hall 
[Megaro] (see p. 52), the

Finally, the Thessaloniki 
Regency Casino is located 
at the 12th km on the 
Thessaloniki – Airport Road 
and is open around the clock.', '77
MUSEUMS
collection includes works of art 
by leading Greek Artists; the 
Byzantine and Postbyzantine 
Icons collection is related to 
the school of Thessaloniki 
and spans 5 centuries (14th 
-19th c.); and a collection of 
360 pieces of art on Greek 
Engraving. Retrospective 
exhibitions of Greek and 
foreign artists are frequently 
arranged in collaboration with 
art foundations in Greece and 
abroad.
GALLERY OF THE 
SOCIETY FOR 
MACEDONIAN STUDIES
It is housed on the top floor 
of the Theatre Building of 
the S.M.S. and it is the first 
visual arts museum in the city. 
It encompasses 300 pieces 
of art (painting, sculpture 
and engraving) by famous 
Greek and foreign artists, 
mostly from northern Greece, 
who represent the major art 
movements of the 20th c.
CULTURAL CENTRE OF 
THESSALONIKI (NATIONAL 
BANK OF GREECE 
CULTURAL FOUNDATION)
It opened to the public in 
1989 and has, ever since,  
been organising major painting,  
sculpture, photography and 
architecture exhibitions in 
collaboration with other local 
educational and cultural 
agencies. Events related to  
the history of the city and  
the greater area also take  
place there. The collection 
includes approx. 250 pieces  
on painting, sculpture, pottery,  
mosaics, murals and 
engraving.', ': 2310 271.195,

National Theatre of Northern 
Greece (N.T.N.G.).  
Established in 1961, it is the 
biggest cultural organisation 
of northern Greece and one 
of the largest in Europe. Its 
stages comprise the Children’s 
Theatre, the Aenaon dance 
theatre (founded in 1982) 
and the Dramatic School 
(founded in 1973); the Opera of 
Thessaloniki has been running as 
a self-supporting section of the 
N.T.N.G. since 1997. It is housed 
in the theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (see p. 25); 
performances are also held in 
the Royal [Vasiliko] Theatre (see 
p. 25), in the Sokratis Karantinos 
Stage, and in the Small Theatre 
of Moni Lazariston (see p. 61), 
as well as in the open-air Forest 
Theatre and Theatre of the Earth

Lazare church in Paris, which

At times, the building was

In 1980 it was declared a

was fully renovated in order 
to accommodate the needs

Capital of Culture events in 
Thessaloniki. Since then it has 
been used as a multi-purpose 
cultural and entertainment 
venue, as two halls of the

Greece (N.T.N.G., see p. 109) 
a Cultural Centre, a café-

housed here. Outdoor space 
theatrical performances,

also take place in the 
premises. The State Museum 
of Contemporary Art is 
housed in one of the older 
structures, covering an area 
of 3,270 m2 (for museum 
collections, see p. 75). 
4.3  Kapnapothikes 
[Tobacco warehouses].
Five old tobacco warehouses 
(tobacco shops) still stand 
in the area, as reminders of 
the city’s booming tobacco 
trade from the mid-19th c. 
until 1990. Most of them were 
built in the Interwar Period and 
bear art deco and Bauhaus 
architectural features.', '1.3  Ethnikis Amynis 
Street.
It leads from the White 
Tower to Syntrivaniou Square 
(see p. 37) and to Agiou 
Dimitriou Street (see p. 39). 
It was laid out after the 1889 
demolition of the eastern 
city walls (a section of its 
Byzantine ramparts still stands 
on Filikis Etaireias Street which 
runs parallel to Ethnikis Amynis 
Street. Until 1912 it was called 
Hamidiye Boulevard, in honour 
of the Sultan Abdul Hamid 
II, as all the buildings along 
the street were his property. 
Today, this is the location of 
the Theatre of the Society for 
Macedonian Studies (1962, 
V. Kassandras) housing the 
State Theatre of Northern 
Greece (S.T.N.G.) as well as  
the Gallery of the S.M.S. (see p. 
77), and the adjacent Building 
A’ of the S.M.S. (1951, A. 
Nikolopoulos), the Hellenic 
Army Club (1953, P. Mylonas) 
and Alexandros cinema. The 
small Tsirogiannis Park is 
situated nearby and around 
it you will find some popular 
cafés and bars.

(see p. 18).

Thessaloniki International 
Fair (T.I.F.) - HELEXPO. 
Since 1926 this has been the 
top trade fair in the Balkans 
and an institution as such in 
the city. It takes place every 
September and it is a major 
trading and commercial event as 
the achievements of the Greek 
industry and entrepreneurship 
are presented to the world. The 
first radio station in southeast 
Europe broadcasted from 
these grounds for the first 
time in 1926, followed by the 
Greek television in the mid 
sixties. Since the 1960s T.I.F. 
established the Greek Film 
Festival (1960, see p. 108) and 
the Thessaloniki Song Festival 
in 1962. In 1999 it was replaced 
by two companies: T.I.F. A.E. 
and HELEXPO A.E. responsible 
for organising over 20 theme 
exhibitions held throughout 
the year on clothing, furniture, 
environment, transport, tourism, 
technology, food industry, 
services etc. Numerous Greek 
and foreign companies and 
agencies participate in the fair 
and over 2 million people visit it 
every year.  
Information: 154, Egnatia St.  
tel.']
reference_contexts: ['The International Book Fair in Thessaloniki is an annual event held in the HELEXPO-TIF exhibition center, attracting professionals and book lovers. It features presentations from Greek and foreign publishers, discussions with writers, and various themed corners for children and teenagers. The Society for Macedonian Studies is a key cultural institution in Thessaloniki, focusing on the preservation and promotion of Macedonian history and culture. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall offers a range of performances, while the National Theatre of Northern Greece is the largest cultural organization in northern Greece, hosting various theatrical productions. The city boasts numerous indoor and outdoor theatre stages, providing diverse entertainment options throughout the year.', 'The area along NEA PARALIA features 12 Theme Gardens covering 76,657 m2, ideal for leisure activities. Notable gardens include the Garden of Alexander, Garden of the Seasons with an amphitheater, and the Garden of Music for events. A 3 km cycle path runs through the area, which also houses the Nautical Club of Thessaloniki. The Thessaloniki Concert Hall, inaugurated in 2000, is a prominent venue inspired by Byzantine architecture, hosting various performances and conferences. Nearby, the Depot Area, named after historic tram depot buildings, retains traces of its older atmosphere. The Allatini Mills and the church of Saints Cyril and Methodius are also significant sites in the area.', "Thessaloniki boasts a rich culinary tradition influenced by Byzantine, Ottoman, and various European cuisines, shaped by its multicultural history. The city's gastronomy features traditional tavernas and restaurants that creatively blend local dishes with gourmet elements. Notable delicacies include gyro, souvlaki, and a variety of soups and pies, alongside seafood specialties like mussel pilaf. Desserts play a significant role, with popular items such as bougatsa and trigona Panoramatos. Koulouri Thessalonikis, a sesame-covered bread, is a common snack sold by street vendors. In winter, locals enjoy salep, a unique hot beverage.", 'The text describes two museums: Noesis and Gerovassiliou Wine Museum. Noesis focuses on interactive learning with exhibits like a car exhibition, a planetarium, a cosmotheatre, and a virtual reality simulator. It also offers educational programs on renewable energy and science. The Gerovassiliou Wine Museum, established in 2008, showcases the history of wine-making and features collections that depict the journey of wine, food pairings, and wine-making equipment. Both museums emphasize visitor engagement and education.', "Eleftherias Square, near the harbor, served as a parking lot and a site of historical significance where 50,000 Jewish residents were gathered by German forces in 1943. A Holocaust Memorial was established in 1997 to commemorate this event. The square is surrounded by notable buildings, including the National Bank of Greece and Alpha Bank, showcasing late neoclassicism and eclectic styles. Kalapothaki Street, starting from the Ladadika area, features pedestrianized sections with neoclassical and Bauhaus-style buildings, popular cafés, and the historic Stein Building. The port area is one of the largest in the southeastern Mediterranean, with a rich history dating back to Constantine the Great's time.", "Thessaloniki's Old Town, untouched by the 1917 fire, features a mix of Macedonian and Ottoman architecture. It was largely uninhabited until the mid-15th century when the Ottomans settled there due to its favorable climate and strategic location. The area retains its original town planning with narrow alleys and squares, attracting artists and students in recent years. After 1922, many refugees moved in, contributing to the area's diverse cultural heritage.", 'Ano Poli, an area of 3,000 hectares, features a small remnant of an old oak forest and has undergone reforestation since the 1930s. It remains a popular destination for hiking, mountain biking, and picnicking despite urban expansion and a significant fire in 1997. Key attractions include the Zoo, which houses various Greek wildlife species, the Forest Theatre for summer concerts, and the Theatre of the Earth, a notable cultural venue. Visitors can access these sites via bus no. 24 from Eleftherias square. The nearby Sykees area retains its charm with Interwar Period houses amidst modern development.', "The Museum of Greek Children’s Art showcases the creativity of children, depicting Greek history, tradition, and culture through their artwork. It is one of the few museums worldwide dedicated to children's art.", 'Thessaloniki has historically been a key stopover for East-West trade. Today, its town center is a prime shopping destination featuring traditional marketplaces and modern commercial areas. Visitors can find a variety of goods, including food, clothing, and antiques, at reasonable prices. Notable shopping spots include Bit-Pazar for second-hand items and the Mediterranean Cosmos Mall, which offers over 200 shops and entertainment options. Other shopping areas cater to lower budgets, such as Venizelou St. and Egnatia St. The city also boasts stylish boutiques and department stores, particularly around Aristotelous Street and Tsimiski Street.', 'The text describes various historical sites in a town, including Main Street, which was lined with shops and public buildings. The Great Thermae was a large public bath complex featuring marble floors and areas for worship and entertainment. The Houses of Zosa and Lida were decorated with mosaics and sculptures. The Roman Forum, dating back to the late 2nd to early 3rd century, included luxury houses and a temple for emperor worship. A polygonal building served as a roofed marketplace, while remnants of Early Christian Walls were found nearby. An episcopal basilica was rebuilt in the 5th century after its destruction in the 4th century. The Praetorium functioned as an inn for officials and travelers, with access to the Main Street Thermae. Additionally, the text mentions a climbing route in Olympus National Park and the Petralona Museum, showcasing prehistoric human activity.', 'The text describes day excursions from Thessaloniki, highlighting the monastic state of Mount Athos, which features 20 inhabited monasteries and is a UNESCO World Heritage site. It provides directions to Petralona Cave, located 53 km southeast of Thessaloniki, accessible by coach and taxi or by car. Additionally, it mentions the Lakes Area northeast of Thessaloniki, a National Park with diverse ecosystems ideal for outdoor activities. The area is managed by an agency that offers tours, and visitors are encouraged to try local fish dishes. Lastly, it notes the town of Lagadas, known for its fire-walking custom and modern spa facilities with historical Byzantine bathtubs.', "Lake Koroneia, also known as Lake Agios Vasileios, has seen a reduction in size and depth due to climate conditions and water resource exploitation. Nea Apollonia, a historic village near Lake Volvi, features mineral springs with therapeutic properties and modern health facilities. Lake Volvi is Greece's second-largest natural lake and a Ramsar site, offering birdwatching and various water sports. The area around Volvi includes tourist attractions and communities like Megali Volvi and Mikri Volvi. Rentina, crossed by the Richios River, is noted for its natural beauty and historical ruins.", 'The text describes various historical sites, including the Sanctuary of Isis, which is half-sunk in water and dedicated to the Egyptian goddess. It also mentions the Sanctuary of Olympian Zeus, completed in the Hellenistic period, featuring a large altar and Roman theatre. The Hellenistic Theatre, built in the 3rd century BC, hosts modern events today. The Sanctuary of Asklipios, active until the 3rd century AD, is noted for a statue of the goddess Hygeia. Additionally, the Cemetery Basilica from the 5th century is described, along with fortified walls originally constructed by Cassander, which have been reconstructed over time.', "The Historic Centre features a blend of modern and traditional Macedonian architecture, including the Acheiropoiitos church, a timber-roofed basilica built in 1818. The Nedelkou Building, constructed in 1909, showcases a mix of architectural styles and now serves as the Mount Athos Centre. The Galerius Arch, a significant landmark from 295-305 AD, commemorates Galerius' victory over the Persians and is a popular meeting spot. Nearby, the Rotunda and Panagia Dexia church, which houses a rare icon, add to the area's historical significance. Plateia Syntrivaniou, named after its marble fountain, completes the cultural landscape.", 'The text describes notable landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the OTE Tower, built in 1969, which serves as a telecommunications hub and features a rotating café with stunning views. It also mentions the Alexandreio Melathron, a historic sports arena constructed in 1966, which has hosted significant events and is now home to the Aris basketball team. Additionally, Angelaki Street is highlighted for its cafés and bars popular among university students, as well as its proximity to several radio stations. The 3rd Army Corps area is outlined, featuring the main headquarters building designed by Italian architect V. Poselli in the early 1900s.', "Thessaloniki hosts several cultural institutions, including museums and galleries showcasing Greek art. The collection features works by prominent Greek artists, Byzantine icons spanning five centuries, and Greek engravings. The Gallery of the Society for Macedonian Studies is the city's first visual arts museum, displaying 300 pieces from major 20th-century art movements. The Cultural Centre of Thessaloniki organizes exhibitions in collaboration with local agencies, featuring around 250 pieces of various art forms. The Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, established in 1997, highlights the history of Greek cinema through exhibits categorized into six timelines.", "The Archaeological Museum of Thessaloniki displays significant art and artifacts from Macedonia, spanning from prehistoric times to late antiquity. The exhibits are categorized into six sections, including the origins of towns, the evolution of Macedonia from the 7th century BC to late antiquity, and the historical significance of Thessaloniki. Notable displays include exceptional gold craftsmanship from ancient cemeteries and a reconstruction of an archaic temple. The museum highlights the region's rich cultural heritage and its transition through various historical periods.", "The Yeni Camii, built in 1902 by architect V. Poselli, served as a mosque for converted Jews and later housed the city's Archaeological Museum. It now functions as a municipal exhibition area with a collection of Roman and Early Christian sculptures. The Hatzimisef Villa, located on Vas. Olgas Ave., was the town's first high school, while the Joseph Modiano villa nearby is currently uninhabited. A bust of King George I, assassinated in 1913, stands at the corner of Vas. Olgas Ave. and Agias Triadas St., crafted by K. Dimitriadis. The Ivan Hatzimisef Villa, built in 1897, now hosts cultural events and an organic food market. Additionally, the building at 34-36 Evzonon Street features classical, baroque, and renaissance architectural styles.", 'The area features historical sites, including a World War II gun emplacement, and is home to diverse salt marshes and wetlands that shelter 178 bird species like flamingoes and cormorants. To reach the location, take the 71 or 71A bus from the Railway Station Stop to N. Michaniona, or use bus lines 02 and 02A to A.S. IKEA station and then switch to buses 72, 72A, or 72B. If driving, follow Ethinikis Antistasis, Georgikis Scholis, and Michanionas avenues.', 'The 6th walk in Thessaloniki highlights several must-see landmarks along NEA PARALIA and VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE. Key attractions include the Monument of Alexander the Great, a large equestrian statue near the White Tower, and the statue of politician Konstantinos Karamanlis. The Makedonia Palace Hotel, a luxury accommodation renovated in the 1990s, is also noted for hosting dignitaries. Another highlight is the Umbrellas sculpture by George Zongolopoulos, a popular photographic spot. Lastly, the Agioi Kyrillos and Methodios Church, dedicated to the saints who spread Christianity to the Slavs, features a well-kept garden.', "The Historic Centre features archaeological sites from the late Roman period, including shops from the 1st to 13th century and the underground Museum of the Roman Forum. A restored Odeon from the 2nd-4th century AD is now used for cultural events. Excavations revealed a round bathhouse from the 1st century BC, along with various artifacts like mosaics, sculptures, and coins. The forum is notable for the 'Enchanted Ones,' a two-storeyed colonnaded archway with Corinthian columns, some of which were moved to the Louvre in 1864. Bit-Pazar, a vibrant market area with antique shops and restaurants, was built in the 1930s and has become popular among students. Nearby, the Jewish Monastirioton Synagogue is the only one that survived World War II. The Experimental School, designed by architect D. Pikionis, was constructed from 1936 to 1938.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki features notable buildings such as the YMCA Building, which showcases a blend of neo-colonial and Byzantine architecture and includes a cultural centre. The Archaeological Museum, designed by P. Karantinos and inaugurated in 1962, is a prime example of modernist architecture in Greece, having undergone renovations to meet contemporary needs. The Museum of Byzantine Culture, built between 1989 and 1993, combines modernism with Greek architectural tradition and is recognized as a historic monument. It includes facilities for exhibitions and events, alongside a café-restaurant and a small amphitheatre.', 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, gastronomy, and lively waterfront.', "Thessaloniki is renowned for its vibrant nightlife, often considered Greece's entertainment capital. The city offers a variety of options, including avant-garde bars, tavernas, ouzo restaurants, and clubs featuring live Greek music, particularly rebetiko. Popular nightlife areas include Ladadika, Kalapothaki Street, and the beachfront cafés. Students frequent Navarinou square, Rotonda, and Angelaki Street, while Ano Poli offers alternative spots for locals. Recently, Valaoritou Street has emerged as a nightlife hotspot, bustling with activity during summer evenings. The Slaughterhouse area features large venues for live Greek music and the city's biggest clubs.", 'The Hellenic Professional Yacht Owners Association is located in Piraeus, while the Thessaloniki Marina is in Aretsou Kalamaria. Various beaches are accessible, including Aretsou beach and those in Halkidiki, which are popular for swimming. Mineral springs and spas in the area include Lagkadas Spa, Nea Apollonia Spa, and Souroti Spring. The urban bus service covers the city, with main termini at key locations and buses running from 5 am to midnight. Tickets can be purchased for single or multiple trips, and must be validated on the first trip. A cultural bus route highlights historical sites, while open-top tourist buses offer guided tours. Makedonia International Airport is 15 km from the city center, with bus services connecting it to major stations.', "The text describes significant Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including the UNESCO-listed Christian monuments that were once a Metropolitan Church and later converted into a mosque. Key features include the 5th-6th century capitals and stunning mosaics, particularly the dome's Ascension of Christ. The Transfiguration of the Saviour Church, built around 1340, showcases typical Byzantine architecture with depictions of Christ's Ascension. The Rotunda, constructed in 306 AD, features a massive dome and was originally a temple before becoming a church and later a mosque, noted for its preserved mosaics. Additionally, the church of Agios Ioannis Prodromos and the baptistery of Agia Sofia are highlighted for their historical significance.", 'Thessaloniki is a city in Greece known for its rich history, vibrant culture, and significant role in the Byzantine Empire. It is the second-largest city in Greece and features a mix of ancient and modern architecture, including Roman ruins and Ottoman-era structures. The city is also famous for its festivals, culinary scene, and lively waterfront.', "The text describes the connection between the town's civic center and various key locations, including Kassandrou Street, Aristotelous Square, and the seafront. It highlights the architectural features of buildings along the street, which house various businesses and institutions. The church of Agia Theodora is noted as a significant landmark at the junction of Aristotelous and Ermou Streets. Nikis Avenue, known as Palia Paralia, runs from the harbor to the White Tower and has historical significance, having been opened by the Turks in 1882. Today, it is a popular area filled with cafés, bars, and pedestrian activity. The avenue features several notable landmarks, including interwar period mansions and the Thessaloniki Club. The text emphasizes the vibrant atmosphere of Nikis Avenue, frequented by locals and tourists alike.", 'The text describes various locations in Ano Poli, Thessaloniki, including the historical significance of the eastern walls and the neoclassical G. Gennimatas hospital. It mentions Agios Nikolaos Orphanos and Kallitheas Square, highlighting the picturesque area and its major streets. Additionally, it notes the former location of the Children’s Museum of Thessaloniki and introduces Seich Sou, the largest forested area near the city.', 'The historic center of Thessaloniki features a shopping mall that was reshaped between 1995-1997, retaining its original exterior while now housing shops, cinemas, cafés, and restaurants around a central atrium. Notable buildings from the early 20th century are located at the junction of Tsimiski and Karolou Dil Streets, currently serving as shops and offices. The traditional market area, west of Aristotelous Street and south of Egnatia Street, is filled with small shops, malls, and arcades dating back to the Turkish Occupation, offering a variety of products including food, spices, and fabrics. Modiano Market, built in 1922, is a glass-roofed structure with 140 food shops and popular restaurants. The Vlali-Kapani and Athonos-Vatikioti Markets, designed by Ernest Hébrard, feature two-storeyed malls with archways and are connected to Aristotelous Street.', 'The Greek National Tourism Organisation promotes tourism in Greece through its website, www.visitgreece.gr.', 'The Palace of Galerius is an open-air archaeological museum in the historic center, constructed in the late 3rd to early 4th century. It is part of the Galerian Complex, which included significant structures like the Hippodrome and Rotunda. The palace served as a residence for emperors until its destruction in the 7th century and is a major monument of Late Antiquity. Key features include the Octagon, an audience hall with elaborate decoration; a colonnaded yard; a two-storeyed tank for water collection; a monumental Basilica used for official gatherings; and a bathhouse with various bathing facilities.', 'Chortiatis is a small suburb located on Mt. Chortiatis, known for its hiking trails and historical significance, including remnants of a Byzantine aqueduct. Thermi, situated 15 km southeast of Thessaloniki, retains a countryside feel and was historically significant as the harbor of ancient Thermi, famous for its hot springs. The central square of Thermi, Paramana Square, is noted for its futuristic design and serves as a hub for local businesses. An artificial lake nearby offers recreational opportunities and hosts the Dam Music Festival in summer, while the Environmental Park provides various sports facilities.', 'Thessaloniki offers various sports facilities, including an 18-hole golf course at Porto Carras Grand Resort and proximity to several ski centers. Notable ski centers include Seli, Elatochori, 3-5 Pigadia, Lailias, Vora, and Falakro, each with different elevations, runs, and amenities. Information for each ski center, including contact details and websites, is provided. Additionally, resources for local tourism, archaeological sites, and weather forecasts are available online.', 'Noesis is a unique science center and technology museum in Greece, completed in 2004, featuring exhibitions, a digital library, and an amphitheater. It can be accessed via public transport or car from Thessaloniki. The seaside areas of Peraia, Neoi Epivates, and Agia Triada, located 20 km from the city center, were settled by refugees in 1923 and have since developed into popular suburbs and resorts. These areas boast Blue Flag beaches, water sports facilities, and a vibrant seafront with tavernas and bars.', 'The text describes various day excursions near Ancient Pella, including Aravissou springs, Platanopotamos Lake, and Dytiko plane-tree forest. It provides directions to Ancient Pella from Thessaloniki and mentions the military Museum of Balkan Wars. Additionally, it highlights the historical significance of Vergina (Aiges), the former capital of Macedon, detailing its importance from the 10th-8th century BC until its destruction by the Romans in 168 BC. The archaeological site is recognized as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, featuring the Royal Tombs discovered by archaeologist Manolis Andronikos in 1977.', "The 6th walk along NEA PARALIA – VASILISSIS OLGAS AVENUE showcases a busy street with impressive late 19th to early 20th-century buildings. Notable sites include Allatini Villa, built in 1898, which served various purposes over the years, including housing the University of Thessaloniki and a military hospital. Casa Bianca, constructed in 1912, features eclectic and art nouveau elements and now hosts a branch of the Municipal Art Gallery. Key national holidays include New Year's Day, Independence Day, and Easter celebrations, which involve various religious and cultural traditions. Other notable festivals include Carnival and Pentecost. For consulate information, contact local authorities in Thessaloniki.", 'The text describes various historical and architectural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Historic Centre, the Jewish Museum, and Venizelou Street, which is known for its eclectic and art deco buildings. The Jewish Museum is located in a historic building from 1904 that survived a fire. Venizelou Street connects Eleftherias Square with the Residency and features interesting architecture. The Pazar (Yahudi) Hamami, built in the early 16th century, showcases Byzantine-style interiors and has a flower market nearby. The Chamber of Commerce & Industry is an impressive neoclassical building from 1930, while the Austrian Tobacco Monopoly Warehouses consist of two art deco buildings from 1926. The text also mentions local shops and markets in the area.', 'The text describes a walking tour along Vasilissis Olgas Avenue, highlighting historical buildings and residences. Notable sites include the Hirsch villa, a former police department, and the Chatzilazarou Residence, built in 1890. The Marokou Residence, previously a boarding school, now houses a Traffic Police Department. The Mehmet Kapanci Villa, constructed in 1893, served various significant roles, including housing military leaders and high schools, and is now part of the Thessaloniki Cultural Centre. The Ahmet Kapanci Villa, built in 1905, features eclectic architectural styles and has housed various organizations over the years, including the Red Cross and NATO services.', 'The text mentions Thessaloniki and its neighboring areas, but does not provide further details or context.', "The text describes notable Byzantine monuments in Thessaloniki, including Agios Panteleimonas Church, which was originally part of a monastery and later converted into a mosque, featuring murals from the 13th-14th centuries. It also highlights Agios Dimitrios Church, the city's patron saint, built in the 7th century on the ruins of an earlier basilica, which was converted into a mosque in 1493 and later restored after a fire in 1917. The church showcases a variety of sculpted decorative motifs and significant mosaics, with a basement that served as a site of martyrdom for Saint Demetrius. Since 1988, it has also functioned as an exhibition area for cultural events.", 'The text provides contact information and websites for various museums and cultural institutions in Thessaloniki, including the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum, Museum of Photography, Olympic Museum, and more. It lists their addresses, telephone numbers, and websites, facilitating access to cultural resources. Additionally, it mentions a collaboration among five museums in Thessaloniki aimed at promoting cultural activities and organizing exhibitions. This collaboration includes the Archaeological Museum, Museum of Byzantine Culture, State Museum of Contemporary Art, Macedonian Museum of Modern Art, and the Teloglion Foundation of Art.', "The text describes several museums in Thessaloniki, including a Holocaust exhibition that memorializes the local Jewish community, particularly the 49,000 members sent to concentration camps. The Museum of the Macedonian Struggle showcases the history of Macedonia's fight for freedom against the Ottoman Turks, with various rooms dedicated to different aspects of this struggle. The War Museum features significant artifacts from modern Greek history, including uniforms and military decorations from the 1821 War of Independence to the 1944 liberation. Lastly, the Ataturk Museum displays exhibits across two floors, highlighting the life and legacy of Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.", 'The area includes historical sites such as the former Turkish army barracks and the War Museum, designed by V. Poselli. It also features the Papafeio Orphanage, a classical style building completed in 1903, which served various purposes including a male boarding school and military barracks. Nearby, the YFANET textile factory was once a major textile unit in Macedonia and is now a venue for events and a library. Additionally, visitors can explore a rare Macedonian tomb from the 3rd century BC and the neoclassical Ippokrateio Hospital built in 1891.', "The Historic Centre features Plateia Dikastirion, a green square where the Court House was planned but halted due to the discovery of the Ancient Roman Forum. The square has a bust of Eleftherios Venizelos, a significant Greek prime minister. Nearby, the Bey Hamami, built in 1444, is the largest Ottoman bathhouse in Greece, known as the Paradise Baths until 1968. The Roman Forum, a 2-hectare area, served as the city's social and religious center during the Roman period, with construction completed in the mid-2nd to mid-3rd centuries AD. The site includes a large square with traces of marble paving and a double underground Cryptoporticus, which likely functioned as a public storehouse.", "The text describes several museums, including the room of Kemal Ataturk's mother, which exhibits his personal items and documents. The Folklife & Ethnological Museum of Macedonia-Thrace, founded in 1957, displays 20,000 objects from the region, focusing on folk art from 1860 to 1960. The State Museum of Contemporary Art, inaugurated in 1997, houses the Kostakis Collection, featuring 1,277 works from the Russian Avant-Garde movement. This museum also has a significant collection of contemporary Greek art and hosts temporary exhibitions. Overall, these museums highlight cultural heritage and artistic movements in their respective regions.", "Aristotelous Square in Thessaloniki is one of Greece's largest and most vibrant squares, operational 24/7. It was part of the Hébrard Committee's urban plan post-1917 fire, fully realized by the early 1960s. The square offers stunning views of the Thermaic Gulf and Olympus massif, featuring monumental architecture that blends Byzantine and European interwar styles. Key landmarks include the Electra Palace hotel and Olympion, the latter hosting the Thessaloniki Film Festival. Aristotelous Street, a pedestrianized historic boulevard, connects to Egnatia Street.", "Thessaloniki, founded in the 4th century BC, has maintained its urban character as a civic center influenced by various empires and multicultural groups. Its rich history includes Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman rule, with contributions from Jews, Latins, Armenians, and Greeks. The city's numerous historical monuments reflect its cosmopolitan nature. The White Tower area is a bustling part of Thessaloniki, where the old seafront meets the new waterfront.", 'Thessaloniki offers a vibrant nightlife with clubs and venues, especially in the summer when many move to open-air locations. Popular areas include Kalamaria and Peraia. The city hosts numerous artistic events year-round, featuring venues like the Thessaloniki Concert Hall and various theaters. Cultural activities include the International Film Festival, Thessaloniki Book Fair, and Demetria Festival. The Thessaloniki Regency Casino operates 24/7, allowing entry for those 25 and older with proper identification. Additionally, traditional products like koulouri and trigona Panoramatos are notable in the region.', "The text describes various streets and locations in Thessaloniki, highlighting their historical significance and current status. Dimokratias Square serves as a key transportation hub, connecting suburbs to the city center and featuring a statue of King Constantine. The area around the square includes mostly unremarkable buildings, but also historic sites like sections of the city's west walls and archaeological monuments. The Railway Station, located on Monastiriou Street, was constructed between 1939 and 1951 and is a notable landmark in the area.", "The historic centre of Thessaloniki features industrial architecture from the late 19th century, with six warehouses built in 1910. Five of these were renovated in 1997 for cultural events, housing institutions like the International Film Festival and the Thessaloniki Cinema Museum. The Customs House, a significant building from 1910, serves as the city's passenger board station. The Ladadika area, spared from the 1917 fire, dates back to the 16th century and was known for its trade in spices and olive oil. Its street layout has remained largely unchanged since the late 19th century, showcasing two-storeyed buildings made of industrial brick and wood.", "The Thessaloniki State Symphony Orchestra, established in 1959, is one of Greece's premier orchestras, performing at the Thessaloniki Concert Hall. The city also offers summer open-air cinemas where films are screened with Greek subtitles. Thessaloniki has a rich sports tradition, hosting major events like the 2004 Olympic Games and various international competitions. Numerous sports facilities are available, including the Kaftanzogleio National Stadium and Poseidonio Sports Centre. The Megas Alexandros International Marathon occurs every spring, starting in Ancient Pella and finishing in Thessaloniki. Information on municipal gyms and sports programs can be obtained from the city's Department of Sporting Events.", 'The text provides information about various churches in Thessaloniki, including their addresses and contact numbers. It also highlights cultural events such as Demetria, an autumn festival featuring theatrical performances and exhibitions, and the Thessaloniki International Film Festival, which has been held since 1960 and showcases films from various sections. Additionally, it mentions the Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.), a major trade event established in 1926 that attracts over 2 million visitors annually and features numerous exhibitions. Contact information for cultural offices and event organizers is also provided.', 'Asprovalta and Nea Vrasna beaches offer marine sports and beach volleyball facilities, with Asprovalta beach being 10 km long and awarded a Blue Flag. Stavros is the largest harbor in the area, while the villages of Vrasna and Ano Stavros feature traditional architecture worth visiting. To reach these locations from Thessaloniki, take bus lines 83, 83M, or 83N to Lagkadas, or travel by coach or car towards Panorama and Kavala. Pikrolimni, located in the Kilkis region, is a shallow lake known for its healing mud with properties three times more concentrated than the Dead Sea. The first Mud-therapy Centre in the Balkans is in nearby Xylokeratia, offering various wellness facilities. Visitors can enjoy mud therapy by the lake in summer, and the center includes a physiotherapy clinic, hotel, and sports fields. Pikrolimni is accessible by car or a daily bus from Thessaloniki.', "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in a city, focusing on Agia Sofia Square, which features greenery and significant buildings like the Longos and Chatzidimitriou Buildings. It highlights the square's pedestrian-friendly areas and a monument commemorating the Genocide of Pontic Greeks. Navarinou Square is noted for its vibrant atmosphere, popular among students, with numerous cafés, bars, and shops. The square also has a fountain and a playground, and visitors are encouraged to explore nearby streets and the church of Nea Panagia, dating back to 1727.", 'The historic centre of Thessaloniki, particularly the Ladadika area, has transformed from a downgraded region post-WWII to a vibrant hotspot with restaurants, clubs, and live music venues since the 1990s. Key attractions include Morichovou square and Petrakaki square, featuring the Ottoman Post Office Mansion. Tsimiski Street, a major commercial hub, connects YMCA square to Ladadika and is known for its shops, offices, and cafés. Notable buildings include the Kazes Building, designed by Xenophon Paionidis in 1924, and Agios Minas Church, which has historical significance dating back to early Christianity.', 'The text describes significant historical sites in ancient Macedonia, including a palace with a peristyle, a monumental gateway, and a temple dedicated to Hercules. It mentions an ancient theatre built around 340 BC, where King Philip II was assassinated. Additionally, it details religious sites near the theatre, including temples dedicated to goddess Euclea and Kyveli, along with remnants of royal votive offerings. The Acropolis features five towers and thick fortification walls, with house foundations dating from the 5th to 1st century BC. The town of Veroia, located near Vergina, was historically important for Macedonians and visited by Apostle Paul, earning the nickname Little Jerusalem due to its many surviving Byzantine churches and a longstanding Jewish presence.', "The text describes various historical and cultural sites in Thessaloniki, including the Hippodrome, which was a center of social activity until 390 AD when a massacre led to its closure. It highlights the Thessaloniki History Centre and the 18th-century Agios Antonios church nearby. The Arched Hall, located at the intersection of Gounari and Svolou streets, was used for symposia and had access to the imperial box in the Hippodrome. Additionally, remnants of a theatre-stadium on Apellou Street are noted, linked to the martyrdom of Agios Dimitrios. The text also mentions three churches on Egnatia Street, particularly the Panagouda Church, built in 1818 on the site of an older church destroyed by fire. The area is rich in history, reflecting the city's cultural heritage.", "Egnatia Street is a historic avenue in Thessaloniki, dating back to Roman times, connecting Dyrrhachium and Constantinople. It serves as a busy shopping area with notable eclectic and art deco buildings from the early 20th century. Key attractions include Kolomvou Square, a lively hub with cafés and restaurants, and the Hamza Bey Mosque, built in 1467, which is currently undergoing renovations. The mosque will soon host an exhibition of archaeological finds from metro excavations. Egnatia Street splits the city's historic center, making it a significant thoroughfare for both locals and tourists.", 'The text describes the historical and cultural significance of suburbs and outskirts of Thessaloniki, including ancient tombs and a Neolithic settlement. It provides directions to Kalochori via bus or car. Kalamaria, a prominent suburb, features green spaces and a shopping center, with a history of Greek refugees settling there in the 1920s. Key sites include Sofouli Street, the Little Palace (formerly a royal residence), and the Kodra former military camp, which is being transformed into a park. Excavations at Kodra revealed a settlement from the archaic and classical periods, possibly linked to Ancient Thermi.', "The text describes various historical and architectural landmarks in Thessaloniki, including the West of the Centre-Stavroupoli inaugurated in 1962, which connects the city to Greece and the Balkans. The Old Railway Station, built in 1894, is now a cargo station and was historically significant during the German occupation. The Top Hane (Vardariou Tower), constructed by the Ottomans in 1546, served as a city stronghold and features well-preserved sections of the old city walls. The De La Salle Complex, built in 1926, now houses the city's Administrative Courts and showcases neobyzantine architecture. Lastly, the Vienni Hotel, established in 1925, reflects eclectic architectural trends and currently accommodates private company offices."]
response:
The cultural events and institutions in Thessaloniki, such as the International Book Fair, the Society for Macedonian Studies, and the National Theatre of Northern Greece, contribute significantly to the city's cultural landscape and community engagement. However, it's worth noting that Thessaloniki also hosts other notable cultural events and institutions, such as the Thessaloniki International Fair (T.I.F.), which is a major trading and commercial event that showcases the achievements of the Greek industry and entrepreneurship. The fair, which takes place every September, has been an institution in the city since 1926 and has played a significant role in promoting Greek culture and trade. Additionally, Thessaloniki is home to numerous cultural venues, including four movie theatres housed in warehouses in the harbour, and a variety of popular cafes and bars.

The International Book Fair, the Society for Macedonian Studies, and the National Theatre of Northern Greece, on the other hand, are more focused on promoting literature, cultural heritage, and the arts. They provide opportunities for cultural exchange and education, and foster a sense of community among residents and visitors alike. The International Book Fair, for example, is a major event that brings together publishers, writers, and book lovers, promoting literacy and a love of reading.
reference: The various cultural events and institutions in Thessaloniki, such as the International Book Fair, the Society for Macedonian Studies, and the National Theatre of Northern Greece, contribute significantly to the city's cultural landscape and community engagement by promoting literature, preserving history and culture, and providing diverse entertainment options.
